Taste of big dark chocolate, cocoa, roasted malt, coffee, char, toast, dark bread, light raisin, toffee, and roasted earthiness. Moderate coffee bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of dark chocolate, cocoa, roasted malt, coffee, char, toast, dark bread, light raisin, and roasted earthiness on the finish for a while. Awesome balance and complexity of dark/roasted malt flavors; with a good bitterness/sweetness balance and no cloying flavors after the finish. Medium-high carbonation and medium-full bodied; with a creamy, chalky, and moderately crisp mouthfeel that is good. Alcohol is very well hidden with only a light warming present after the finish. Overall this is a highly excellent imperial stout. All around great balance and complexity of dark/roasted malt flavors; and very smooth to sip on for the ABV. A highly enjoyable offering.
Great poor, solid beer without doing anything out of the ordinary, quite overrated imo.

Bottle from 1-24-12. Pours deep black with an immense brown head that has outstanding retention and leaves plenty of lacing. This is a gorgeous pour. The aroma has a nice milk chocolate quality, some roastiness, light coffee, a slightly lactic quality. The taste has a big espresso coffee, milk chocolate, then it finishes with a roasted, bitter, dark chocolate assault on the tongue. Delicious!!!

Pegged this for imperial stout and I would describe the appearance as old crude oil. Looks like the seagulls fouled by the Exxon Valdez. Smells of Italian coffee and chocolate brownies. Rich, bittersweet chocolate taste like high end dark/milk chocolate mix bars you see in nice goody shops. In terms of the alcohol it feels explicitly powerful without coming off as over muscled. Full bodied and foamy yet also has a crispness to it not found on big stouts. Very high quality.

2011 Oct bottle, 2 years old from my cellar. Pours nearly black with a big dense partially lasting brown head with quickly diminishing lace and legs. Aroma is big deep roast and rich milk chocolate cake with hints of vanilla and nuts. The flavor is like a not especially sweet mocha. The bitterness is deep but balanced but sweetness and some umami. The feel is viscous, fairly lively, woody, boozy, and partially dry at the end. This seems every bit a stout. Its huge and intensely flavored at that but well rounded enough. At 2 years old I would have expected it to show more obvious signs of age but there arent. 

I drank this next to the Older Viscosity of the same year. Above was my impression without tasting the Older. The older is obviously has way more whisky happening but its much more still, hot, rich, intense, and is showing more signs of age notably much more soy / umami.
From tap. Full chocolate aroma and taste. Roasted coffee aftertaste. Long warm chocolate finish.

Maravilloso aroma a café, aunque no me tire mucho. En boca, aún más impresionante. Crema pura, con dejes alcohólicos. Si quieres, ¡es el desayuno de los campeones!

¿Strong Ale? ¡Imperial Stout descaradísima!
Good big beer. Had at the beer geeks of northwest arkansas. Don't have other tasting notes recorded.
Dark thick and black, it blocks out light like an eclipse. Smells sweet with hints of leather and raisins. Starts thin and wet, thickens up coffee choco taste comes on and it drys out.

Bomber from Antioch. Bottle date of 3/15/13, and cellar ageed for 3 months. Pours a thick black with a brown head leaving a lot of lace that lasts and last. Aroma has molasses, chocolate and heavy roasted malts. Taste is of bakers chocolate, espresso, roasted caramelly malts and sweet vanilla. Full bodied and thick. Alcohol more present down through the glass. Finishes choco-coffee bitter with some caramelly sweetness, a bit shorter than one would expect, with lingering alcohol. The "older" version was thicker and more luscious, but this one is nice as well.
Dark brown in colour.Humble, but decent, aroma. Taste like a good old ale with a bit of sting.

Even with being likely handled improperly, we don't get really much barrel-aged qualities. Surprising lack of sweetness too. Not a bad beer, but certainly not worth more than about $6-8. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
UPDATED: AUG 27, 2013 Bottle from Kyle pours black with low head, great smooth stout with a nice coffee profile, awesome beer

Bottle. Pours black with a big mocha head that dwindles to finger thickness. Aroma is burned malts, tobacco and leather, as well as notes of wine barrels. Full, creamy and smooth body, with average to fizzy carbonation. Flavour is actually quite bitter of grapefruity hops, as well as nice dark notes of coffee, chocolate, tobacco and leather before the bitterness once again dominates the nice long finish.

22 ounce bottle poured into a brandy snifter. Pours a thick, dark brown with a dense, khaki colored head of foam. Really steady retention. Thick sheets of lacing down the sides of the glass. The aroma has a lot of earthy, roasty overtones to it. Burnt brown sugar, leather, walnuts each come to mind. Some smoke sneaks in, too. In the taste, I find a brash, deep bitterness that smacks you in the face with how earthy it is. The oak notes come through in the finish very nicely. Very thick mouthfeel with just an ever so slight tingle of carbonation. Theres a pleasant warming sensation on the swallow and all the way down the throat. Really, quite good. This beer would kick some ass paired with a medium bodied cigar.
Pours oily black with creamy tan head. Nose is of toffee, chocolate and sweet malt. Tast is thick, oily, smokey, chocolate. Creamy mouth feel. Sweet finish.
Black with cramy brown head. Aroma of coffee and chocolate. Flavors the same with a bit of molasses. Nice creamy mouthfeel. Nailed a pairing with some chocolate cake.

On tap at Brodys in Jamul. Pours black with very little head. Nose is malt, coffee, chocolate; flavor follows with roast, licorice, coffee, chocolate. Sweetness is balanced by bitter notes on the back end. Very good.

Pours black with sediment and very nice tan head. strong roasted malt aromas. Lactose and dark chocolate and anise too. Strong bitter malty flavours. Dark chocolate notes as well. Really good. Cant wait to try its big brother.. Older viscosity.

UPDATED: JUL 23, 2013 Thanks cards04 for this one, who brought it back from a road-trip to Denver. Well, anyway, thanks, cards04 for a sample of this beer. Dark body, off white head. Tastes quite matlty, somewhere in between a stout and an olde ale. Sweeter than a stout but quite dark and roasted as well. Quality.

22 ounces in a tulip glass. It takes a big appetite to polish off a bottle of Old Viscosity...find some friends to share it with. It appears dark brown-black, opaque, thick brown foam that sticks around until it curdles on top. Aromas include heavy coffee grind, dark chocolate and roasted oatmeal. The taste is pretty much more of the same: bitter coffee, shredded and toasted malt, dark chocolate, anise and big time booze. That last part made it a bit too rough for me, and it tastes even higher than 10% abv. Heavy bodied, and pungent mouthfeel. Overall, it has a beastly taste volume level, but there isnt much novelty outside of its flavor and body magnitude. When beers get this huge, theyre sorta unwieldy.

Bottle from Binnys in Orland Park, aroma of big roasted malt and coffee roast. Taste is chocolate coffee roasted malt, super smooth finish.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Pours black with tan head. Roasted malts, dark chocolate and coffee aroma. Malty, woody taste, with coffee, slightly sweet. Full body.
Pours black with beige head. Aroma of roasted malt, wood, aromatic hops and licorice. Flavour is licorice, roasted malt, coffee and licorice.

Dark chocolaty colored body. Big tan head, but bot as big as the one in the picture though. Aroma of chocolate, licorice, barley, straw. Tastes strongly of coffee and char. I assume the oak barrels it was aged in were burnt on the inside. Thick for a non-porter but not nearly as thick as an imperial stout and definitely not as think as used oil. If you like your beers founded on lies, you might like this one. Alcohol is well hidden behind the wall of char.
Pours dark, rich, and foamy, with light brown head. Smells of malt and molasses. Thick, creamy, full bodied beer. Glad I bought 3 when i had the opportunity.

Bottle shared with Edu. Black colour with a light biege head, with medium duration and good lacing. Aroma is toasted malts with notes of black coffee. Flavor has smoked wood notes, licorice, black coffee, alcoholic, and black chocolate. The final is alcoholic with a good duration very good compensated with a decent bitterness.

bottle 3-6-2013
large creamy light brown head
black color
chocolate, coffee , pepper
full body , lively carbonation
sweet start , light acidic with bitter ending

mmmm This is the real thing. Heavy coffee, nut, oak aroma. and booze. Viscous and oily spreading heavy bitter booze love all over your palate. Perfect with some dark chocolate and as a nightcap. Bottled 11/2012 Glorious

UPDATED: JUN 1, 2013 dark brown colour, huge long lasting brown head; aroma of roasted coffee, dried dark berries, some smoke and dark chocolate; taste of heavy roasted malts...and it is, in fact too dominant to feel anything else (maybe some smoked taste can be felt); I accept its greatness, but a bit too much for me
On tap on brewery. Poured a dark brownish black with a small brown head. Aromas of dark fruit, spice and honey.

One of my all time solid favorites. Thick stout base heavy on roasted malts, without a hint of astringency. The barrel-aging infuse a certain sweetness to the brew that blends perfectly with the malt flavor. Smooth sipping. Big at 10%, but hides its ABV very well. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours dark brown, almost black, with two fingers of thick tan head. Smells of oak and coffee. Tastes of oak, coffee, roasted malts, and alcohol. It is a thick beer that coats the tongue nicely. Absolutely delicious.

65 cl bottle from Vinmonopolet Vika. Pours a  dark brown almost black with a huge brown head. Aroma of roasted malt, sweet dark fruit and coffee. Flavour of wood and coffee with notes of dark chocolate and some dark fruits. Medium carbonation, low bitterness, oily/sticky mouthfeel, full bodied.
Complex and interesting beer.
Big head, nice color. Roasted coffee, mocha, vanilla, earth, anise, very mild oak.  Medium finish not too heavy, light hops. Nice.

Bottle. Pours a deep black color with a lacing tan head. Strong, brown sugar aroma withn some dark chocolate in the background. Strong licorice flavor with a hint of brown sugar. Complex finish with the alcohol lingering.
Bottle 0.65l at Gallows Bird, Espoo. Colour is black with small brownish white head. Aromas and flavours: Oil, smoke, licorice, wood and roasted malts.
Pours from bottle black with an inch of khaki foam. Not a long on the nose. Definitely feels like motor on the tongue. Lots of roasted malt ant licorice. Finish lingers a bit. Solid for style.

Pours a super thick dark brown almost black with a big fluffy brown head. Lots of big toasted malt on the nose, sweet dark fruit, molasses, coffee and oak. The toasted malt and oak are really strong in the taste, dark bitter chocolate, dark coffee, and some dark fruit. Full bodied, very thick and viscous. Quite a good beer, but I think I prefer older viscosity.
Pours pitch black with brown head. Tight bubbles, little carbonation. Smells like coffee, chocolate, oak, and cigar ash. Full body coats your palate and lingers.

Smell of coffee and cocoa. Black with high brown head. Aroma of ash, coffee, cocoa, tar. Bitter. Viscous, living up to the name. Barbed. Awesome attitude. 

Comparison between Harviestoun Old Engine Oil and this: OEO is oily and droopy, this one is ashy and barbed.

650 ml bottle. Bottled 8/7/12. Kaisla, Helsinki, Finland.
Pitch black colour with a small tan head. 
The aroma is very strong roasted malt, sweet caramel, dark bread, ash, coffee, soy sauce, mild salt and mild dark chocolate. I would call the aroma complex. 
The flavour is at least as strong. Roasted malt, grassy bitter hops, ash, coffee bitterness, salt and mild dark chocolate. 
Alcohol is very well hidden. I have a bomber in front of me. Thatll be a challenge. Its warming... like hell. But the flavour is very enjoyable and lingering. Its absolutely great brew but also very nice beer to share. Wow! What a beer.

Aroma of dark fruit and some toffee. Full bodied and silk texture and tastes of dark fruit also and some toffee with hint if licorice and finish of oak with a little bitterness

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Negro opaco, espuma beige densa y duradera. Aromas a chocolate, bizcocho, y torrefacto. Si se agita se desvelan matices alcohólicos. En boca tiene una progesividad extraordinaria. Comienza con un sabor dulce achocolatado y termina con un amargor que va creciendo en intesidad y  que en el regusto se une a un toque alchólico equilibrado. Bien carbonatada, con una densidad media-alta, se bebe muy fácilmente. ¡¡Un pedazo de birrote!!
Huge tan head on top of dark body.  Flavors of chocolate and roasted malt blanket the high ABV.  A nice long finish hints at some dry bitterness.

A - pours pitch coal black with extremely high super fluffy amazingly sticky head. S - coal, coffee, chalky chocolate, molasses. Subtle alcohol, vegetal malts. M - medium body. Less than I expected. High carb. Sharp mf. Long bitter very dry end that leaves my mouth sticky. T - vegetal malts, coca I nibs, bitter espresso, coffee grounds, come on strongest. Notes of molasses chips, milk chocolate, oak tannins, grasses and coal. Bitter toasted malts. O - quite good. Bitter and relatively rounded. 3.7

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured from a bomber very dark brown with a great tan head aroma is coffee dark chocolate and malts very smooth mouth and great chocolate malt and coffee flavors great beer a must try!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draft at Churchkey for CBC. Poured a near pitch black color with a small, but thick mocha head. Aroma was roasted malts  - notes of chocolate and some coffee. Flavor was roasted chocolates, with plenty of malts, bitter notes. Some slight alcohol legs on this one - a little burn but a lot more mellow than I expected it to be.

Sample from a bottle, thanks to beerpig317. He tells me that this is "probably a couple year old bottle". As far as I can tell from my plastic cup, pretty much black color. One finger thick, super thick tan head that just stays. Thick lace. Dark fruit aroma in the nose. Big roast in the flavor. Bigger body, but kind of dry overall, not oily like I expected. Lighter, softer, very smooth carbonation. Very bitter overall. Some light licorice / anise type flavors. Really mild bite. Light roasty coffee. Great stuff.

Pours extremely dark brown with a yellowish brown head. Smells strongly of caramel and toffee and dark fruits. Taste is dark fruits and toffee with hints of booze. Full-bodied with a slick texture and soft mouth-carbonation, Port Brewing Old Viscosity finishes with a dark fruit-like kick.

Pours dark brown with a thick butterscotch colored head. Dark chocolate and strong coffee aroma with a bit of grassy notes at the end. Flavor is similar, wiry the addition of just enough hop bitterness and oak to balance the sweetness...almost a smoked porter/imperial stout hybrid. Warming from the alcohol to finish with smokey oak to finish. Palate is full bodied and sticky... But very good. Great beer from one the best breweries on the planet.

Bottle sample.
Very dark brown, almost opaque, nice mocha head.
Roasted coffee aroma, dark chocolate and espresso notes.
Dark chocolate flavors, roasted malts, medium bitterness, earthy notes, slight acidity.
Not creamy, medium bodied, balanced and nice but not very complex.
Bottle share at Hunaphu Day. Deep brown pour with a tan head. Aroma of toffee, chocolate, earthiness with hint of smoke. Flavor is similar with a thick sweet body and some booze.
Bottle pours dark amber with a tan foam head. Nose of caramel toffee and slight pine. Taste follows with addition of roast and a note of nut. Body is solid but the ABV makes his a sipper.

(Bottle 1PINT 6FL.OZ.)
Cocoa, bitter chocolate, malty aroma. Opaque black color. All time creamy brown head. Light sweet, medium bitter, light chocolate taste. Medium-full body. Oily texture. Very dry, light alcohol warm finish.

Black color with 1 finger brownish head. Aroma of chocolate, nuts, cocoa, coffee, smoke, vanilla, cream. Taste is light sweet, just a bit sour and then dry and bitter, quite complex. Medium body, creamy texture, soft carbonation. Really nice even my girlfriend likes it a lot. Amazing with chocolate.
220213. Bottle at OHaras, Tampere. Pours dark deep amber with a small head. Aroma vanilla, nuts. Nutty dry taste. Medium palate. Not Bad.
bottle 65cl @ OHaras. pours black with a beige head. coffee, dark malts in the aroma.sweet vanilla flavor.

On tap 4 oz. pour at the Lost Abbey tasting room in San Marcos, CA.

Opaque, brown-black with thin tan head and excellent lacing.

Aroma of chocolate, roasted malt, coffee, oak, toast, vanilla, dark fruit and smoke.  Very complex flavor.

Medium/full body and medium/high carbonation.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
0.65l bottle. Black body,  light brown creamy head. Very roasty aroma with plums and caramel. The flavor is roasty too with huge caramel notes, plums and a floral hop bite. Oily texture. Very nice.

Pours dark, rich, and foamy, leaving a think two fingers of cappuccino colored head that reduces to a thin foamy slick that stays long. Lots of sticky lacing.
Smells of toasted malt and molasses with a soft hint of booziness that allures.
Thick, creamy, full bodied beer thats very satisfying to drink. Malty sweetness up front and mild hoppy bitterness back. Not greatly complex but a quite nice.
Id buy it again.

Bottle. Pours near black with a long lasting lacing moderate beige head. Aroma is quite hoppy and estery, hay, bubblegum, roasted malt, toffee, cherries, licorice, molasses, vinous, vanilla, ,light soy and oak. Taste is medium+ sweet and bitter. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is almost average. Finishes is dry, quite hard roasted malty bitter, hoppy and alcoholic. Quite stoutish. This beer somehow works better than the sum of the parts, its not terribly coherent or balanced, but ends up charming anyway.

Bottle. Dark brown with a lasting creamy beige head that leaves good lacing. Aroma is vinous, light bubblegum, roasted malt, grain, some dry and bitter herbal hop notes, soy sauce, brown sugar. Taste is medium+ sweet and heavy bitter. Medium+ body, oily texture, medium carbonation. Roasted bitter dry finish.

Pours jet black with the best looking head Ive ever seen on a beer. Really thick with amazing lacing. Aroma of dark malts, spice, licorice, soy sauce, oak barrel, and chocolate. Taste is super roasty with a spicy component that I cant quite nail down. Also getting some chocolate, soy sauce, and roast. Nicely carbonated, slightly thin, but delicious.

Pours an inky dark almost black with a light chocolate head which hangs around for quite a while.  Aroma of coffee and chocolate.  Taste is expresso bean, burnt chocolate, vanilla and oak with a very present alcohol coming in late.  Chewy and sticks to the ribs.  A great winter nights offering.

Bottle trade thanks Aaron.  Pours motor oil black w/ a dark beige head.  Smell is coffee and vanilla with great roasted malt background.  Taste of nice roasted coffee beans and chocolate that ends smooth with a lingering bitter aftertaste.  Overall this is a great beer that hides the abv very well and can be very dangerous if I had multiple bottles.

Deep dark brown, but black in glass. Beige lacing on top. Heavy aroma is bitter - sweet, salty licorice, french roast coffee, milk chocolate, alcohol, ripe dark fruits. Roasted dry, crisp feel, medium body, long roasted and bitter finish, alcohol in flavor also. Not that smooth, bit too evident alcohol, basic flavor is ok. Bit rough and rude kinda beer.

UPDATED: AUG 11, 2013 On tap at Black Bottle Brewery. Dark brown with a tan head and nice sticky lacing.  Roasted malt aroma, chocolate and coffee. Full body, creamy and chewy.  Rich roasted flavor, toasted/burnt malts, chocolate, coffee and vanilla.  Stout-like.  Complex flavor and easy to drink.
6 fl. oz. bottle @ Harrys. Pours pitch black with a low tan head. Aroma is roasted malts and coffee. Flavor is roasted malts with coffee, alcohol and some hops. Good stuff.

The body was dark brown (27 SRM) in color, with ruby highlights when held against a light.  The head was beige in color, with a craggy appearance and clumpy lace.  The smell was dominated by cocoa powder, with a minor contribution by vanilla, and just a hint of toffee.  The taste had coffee, maple syrup, vanilla, and burnt toast in it.  The beer was quite astringent and drying in the finish, with lingering, warm, alcohol burn.  The oak barrel aging was quite evident in the character of this beer.  The fresh beer drank a little hot for my tastes, and would probably be better with some age on it.

Pours a deep dark, thin, blackness with full khaki head.  Nose is oaky with roasted malts with some hop presence and perhaps oatmeal.  Flavor is fully oaked with some chocolate notes and hops throughout.  Not an overbearing hop, but its definitely there.  Lighter body with thin sparse lacing.  Not bad, not my favorite American Strong.
Bomber pour. Thick black/brown pour brown head. Good coffee taste. Really rich. Super goodd

On tap at Hops & Pie. Pour is pitch black with a fluffy brown head and great lacing. Big roasted chocolate aroma, coffee, dark fruits, vanilla, bread, red grapes, oak, and smoke. Taste is big roast, and dark chocolate, with nice vanilla, cinnamon, and wood notes, ending with a big toasty finish. Creamy mouthfeel with soft carbonation. Super well-balanced and not a touch of alcohol in sight; hard to believe its 10% ABV. Nice stuff!

Bomber. Pours an opaque brown black with an espresso colored head, good retention. (Before I go any further, Ill just cut to the chase - this looks and smells  like a stout, with a mouthfeel more like a porter, but somehow not categorized as either, which is puzzling). Nose is roasty and full of butterscotch, maple, vanilla. Mouth is medium bodied (definitely not anywhere close to viscous.... but that would be gross), leading with a sweetness, then some roast, coffee, butterscotch, cocoa and a slightly bitter finish with a noticeable warmth on the way out. Whatever this is suitable to classify it as, its a really nice brew on a cold Chicago evening by the (almost dead) Christmas tree.

Black pour, with an impressive, thick, rolling head that lasts, and leaves lots of lacing on the glass. Aroma is roasted malt and dark chocolate, but relatively mild. Flavor is primarily roasted malt, a little dark chocolate, and just enough bitterness to keep it in balance. This is not complex, and there are not a lot of interesting flavors in the background. No hint of alcohol, and I do not really pick up barrel notes. Not thin, but definitely thinner than I expected. Surprisingly easy to drink. I like this a lot even though its not what I was expecting. Worth having again and again. Nice one.

Pours a dark black brown with a nice mocha head. Nose is malty and chocolate with some alcohol poking through.Taste is predominately sweet dark chocolate with  tasty malt. Finish is sweet and chocolate. Carbonation s soft and texture heavy . Very very nice. Quaff Score 9 / 10

Pours black with a brown head and roasty aroma of chocolate and roasted malt. Taste is burnt and toasty, of chocolate, roasted malt, liquorice and caramel with a long, sweet, warming finish. Very tasty brew

Bottle at JF tasting, thanks to an IP trade with Kurt - 29/12/12.
Very dark mahoogny brown veering towards black with a thin tan head that clears to the edge.
Nose is dark malt, toffee, molasses, touch of chocolate, a little hop presence, treacle.
Tast follows the nose, chocolate carries a little more presence, dark toffee, a little booze, molasses, tar.
Full bodied beer with soft carbonaton and a little booze in the finish.
Decent stuff, well balanced, complex, the booze is well integrated.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Pours black with a nice a nice beige head. Smells sweet with noticable alochol content. Very smooth taste of black and choclate malts. Very smooth with a molases quality to it. Very mild hops on the back note, but overall a malt dominated beer. Overall a great cold weather beer for sipping by a fire.

pitch black pour with a frothy tan head. nice lacing throughout the glass. dark aroma of roasted malts, cocoa and earthy. sweet up front, chocolate flavors paired with some caramel and molasses. dry finish with the roasted malts shining through accompanied by some dark fruit flavors.

Aromas of wheat, roasted barley, and hops. Blackish mahogany with a thin foam rim. Complex flavors of raisins, burnt caramel, molasses, resin and strong roasted malts. Hops are present in the back of the palate and there is a massive alcohol sting on the finish. Overall, this is a very thick and aggressive beer boasting massively complex flavors. Really something to cherish. Id give this an A+ rating.

22 oz bottle from Total Wine in Tucson, served in a tulip. Pours deep black with a small tan head that fades quickly to a thin cover and leaves a small amount of fine lace. On the nose, there are big notes of chocolate, molasses and vanilla, along with oak, earth and just a hint of hops. The flavour is quite sweet throughout with lots of caramel, chocolate, molasses and subtle coffee notes. The herbal, earthy hops enter towards the finish and add balance. The finish is long and malty with chocolate, oak and roasty malts that go on forever. On the palate, it is full in body with a smooth, creamy, slightly chewy texture and soft carbonation. Overall, this is an amazing dark ale. I love the interplay between the chocolate and oaky notes. A beautiful ale, comparable to its older sibling. 2012-03-13
Pours black..brown head..aroma is extremely strong alcohol and chocolate.. Taste is same with some nut and light prune..  excellent beer

Apariencia: color negro como el aceite usado de la camioneta de un granjero de Arkansas, carbónico muy escaso, corona escasa pero compacta y con buena retención. 
Aroma: intensidad media, muy equilibrado y complejo, notas de licor, fruta oscura, pasas, ciruelas, punto alcohólico, parecido a una cuádruple. 
Sabor: distinto del esperado, muy intenso, con mucho cuerpo, muy interesante y diferente, ligeramente amargo, sabor larguísimo, frutas oscuras, chocolate, ligeramente alcohólica, muy compleja pero también equilibrada.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2013 Pitch black (who would have thought?) with a small offwhite head. Aroma or roasted barley and coffee. Taste follow suit with a nice burnt flavor followed by an appreciated sweetness. Cant say I felt much signs of barrel aging but it is smooth. Light carbonation with a medium body, this is a nice change of pace in this era of super potent imperial stouts. A nice and boozy stout stout.

Tasting at a good basement temp not chilled. Aroma of Coffee, chocolate, cereal. Light to medium bitter taste that sweetens at the back end with vanilla and wood. Creamy and slick though not as thick as I expected, alcohol sits nicely in the throat while  coffee and chocolate stay around for awhile. Acidity is present throughout and lingers. This one keeps your attention.

22 oz bottle pours black with a huge mocha head and good lacing. Aroma has lots of roasted mats plus coffee, vanilla, tobacco, some dark fruits. Taste is initially sweet with a dry finish.  Body is only medium, with more carbonation than I expected.  A very good, unclassifiable beer.  I love Imperial Stouts, Black IPAs, and Porters, and this one has some of each style.

Bomber into Duvel Tulip.  Black with big foamy tan head, like root beer float foam.  Aroma is quite muted, some dark malt but not much else.  The beer opens quite smooth with some dark roasted malt sweetness, then comes some molasses, coffee, and chocolate.  The finish is all coffee and woody acidity.  Carbonation is low, body is medium thick.  This is a nice beer, I can understand the high ratings, but the acidic/coffee finish is just not up my alley.

Pours a pitch black color with a big frothy, tan head that lasts a long time.  Huge lacing on the glass.  Aromas of tobacco, vanilla, cream, cocoa, wood, and light roast.  Smells delicious.  Taste is delicious too, my kinda beer.  Very creamy, packed with vanilla, cream, and tobacco flavor.  Light roast, chocolate, and wood notes.  Finish is smooth and creamy, lingering cocoa taste.  Full body, creamy mouthfeel with soft carbonation.  Reminds me a bit of HOTD Adam but creamier and not quite as good.  Still fairly unique to me though and worth trying.

Recommended by someone at Total Wine who was helping me find beers high up on the 2008 Beer Advocate list.
Im not a fan of stouts, but this one is slightly better than Guinness with a more interesting taste.

Its a very good beer, but in a bizarre way I was a little dissapointed.  It tastes exactly like an IS, down to the intense coffee flavor.  It forms an extremely strong head like an American Strong, but the taste is not distinctive at all.  A better example would be the hair of the dog series, Matt especially.  This is really good, but its not unique, Im more looking forward to the older viscosity, hopefully its a little different

Bottle @ home.... it pours pitch black with a large long lasting fluffy brown head.....The aroma is roasted malts, licorice and some vanilla notes.... The flavor is roasted malt, licorice, vanilla and ashes..... Oily texture.... nice brew....

Bottle @ home shared with Dutchdrebus. Very dark almost pitch black color, small to medium sized brown head that leaves a fair lacing but diminishes fairly quickly. Smell malts,  roastyness, lightly alcohol, lightly earthy, hops. Taste roastyness, malts, hops, lightly alcohol, lightly liquor, lightly wood, lovely bitterness. Not as good as the older viscosity but certainly a very good beer indeed! Full body, medium to full carbonation. Great!

Bottle thx to Benzai, thx for sharing! Pitch black oil with a brown head that doesnt last long. Smells dark chocolate, roasty, coffee. This will be a treat. Tastes chocolate, roasty, coffee, sweet. Great taste. This beer could use a little bit less carbo and a bit more body, but other than that its great. Im going to enjoy this one.

22 oz bottle, bottled 9/7/02 served in a Duvel tulip. Pours a rich black with a thick. dark tan head that takes forever to shrink down and leaves ok lacing. Aroma is roasted malts, oak, raisins, molasses, and a sharp hoppiness. Taste is more malts. Roasted barley, smoke, wood, and somewhat piney hops dominate. There is coffee and bakers chocolate as well. Mouthfeel is medium and alcohol is well hidden. It drinks like a porter meets black ipa. Real good.

Very enjoyable, but not nearly as aggressive as I was hoping.  Aroma is dominated by roasted coffee, then oak and bitter chocolate. Not very viscous, which really lets me down, and a bit overly carbonated. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

bottle 22oz Ordered of internet. Pours a dark molasses with frothy and creamy smooth head. Aromas of roasted malts, caramel, chocolate, vanilla, smoke, and oak. Flavors chocolate, roasted malts, chicory root, oak, light smoke, caramel, and wood. Alcohol only noticeable through the nose. Medium sweet, lightly smokey, with medium to high bitterness. Was expecting more on the thickness but still well rounded and great. Solid over the top imperial stout (this is no ASA to me).

Smells like roasted grain with a hint of cocoa coffee. Lighter on the palate than expected. A hop bite after some smokey roasted malt. Very flavorful. Probably best described as a porter. But has enough hop bite for the black ipa category. A good changeup from overly sweet stouts. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
From a 12 oz bottle at a tasting. Pours black with a tan head. Caramel s d raisins in the nose. Roasted coffee, chocolate and a bitter finish.

Bomber bought some place I cant remember. Pours vary dark brown, almost black, with a frothy goldenish pale brown head that slowly dissipates while leaving some thick sticky lacing on the glass. Smell is sweet, malty and tiny spicy with roasted malts, caramel, sweetened coffee, charred wood, vanilla fudge, black pepper, alcohol, sweet liquorice candy, roasted oatmeal flakes, cookie dough, dark chocolate, bourbon, raisins and hints of port wine. Taste is sweet, bitter, tiny sour and malty with roasted malts, caramel, vanilla fudge, dark roast coffee, bitter chocolate, whiskey, burnt raisins, resinous wood, freshly cut grass, toasted cereal, black pepper, liquorice hard candy, moist soil, molasses, toffee and warming alcohol. Mouthfeel is soft, silky, slightly creamy, slightly boozy and near full bodied. Finish is sweet and bitter with roasted malts, dark roast coffee, liquorice hard candy, resinous wood, pine, whiskey, burnt caramel, toffee and alcohol. Quite tasty

Bottle shared with (and courtasy of) Veitafan. Has a hazy black colour with a frothy greyish beige head. Aroma of nice roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, lactose, leather and some spices. The flavour is also very nice with lots of roasted malt, coffee, dark chocolate and anis. Has a slick and oily mouthfeel, and a light bitterness. A wonderful and well-balanced beer.

(From notes 29 Oct, 2012) Bottle. The head is not very large, but compact and uniform in structure, brown color. The beer is nearly black. Aroma is very sweet; vanilla, sugar, chocolate milk and coffee. Flavor is bitter, dark roasted coffee and malty. Carbonation surprisingly high, but this feels soft on the palate though. Finish is bitter coffee.Good stuff. Compared to Older Viscosity, which costs a lot more, this one is just as good. Alcohol wasnt noticeable in this one.
660ml bottle from Beermerchants.com. Very dark brown colour, flat, no head. Fruity malt aroma. Dark chocolate & coffee flavour. Smooth & sweet. Better than I thought it would be.

Bottle. Black with tan head. Chocolate, wood and dark fruits, plum, dates in the aroma. Taste has more of the same. Well balanced, full bodied with a slightly bitter finish. Nice, quite mellow and subtle, not big in any direction

It's a good beer! Strong. Dark ale. Sweet fruity aroma. Light carmel palate. Light head. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Roast, nuts, and caramel in a malty, bready aroma.  Flavor starts with roast and some fruit, and finishes with roast coffee/chocolate bitterness.  Hides the alcohol really well.  Definitely worth seeking out.
Fantastic beer. 10%abv but alcohol does not overpower the flavor. Roasted malty nose. Rich tasting with slight oaky taste. Highly recommend. Thanks for sharing the beer Ben4321

Location: 22 oz bottle from Sparrow-Downtown, 10/14/12


Aroma: The nose is roasted malts, a little bourbon, wood/oak, some vanilla, and a little chocolate

Appearance: Pours a thick, black color with a thumb-worth of foamy brown head

Flavor: The taste is roasty and a little sweet, with bozzy notes, oak/wood, and a bit of a hop backing

Palate: The body leans full, with some thickness to it, an average carbonation, and some decently hidden alcohol

Overall Impression: 
This is a very good beer that I have definitely had before, but has escaped rating until.  I like this one quite a bit, they did a really good job here.

Viscous really black ale with a creamy Brown head. Smells like chocolate, caffee and molasses. A perfect one

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
UPDATED: OCT 31, 2012 Great beer. Tastes almost more like an excellent imperial porter than an imperial stout or traditional old/strong ale, but there are some great flavors going on in this beer.

Bottled. Pours opaque and deep brown to black with a large tan head. Excellent lacing. Nose of roasted malt, chocolate, bourbon, molasses and caramel. The flavor is sweet with roast, bourbon and ends up with some bitterness and alcohol notes. Full bodied, oily to syrupy texture and soft CO2. A great btew.

22 oz. bottle, consumed on 10-6-12. Labeled as Bottled 1-24-12. Yeasty aroma features chocolate, raisin, bran muffin, coffee, mocha, toffee, rich caramel, plum, tobacco, vanilla, and licorice scents. The aroma comes pouring out. Complex and appetizing smell but not as amazing as it could be. Pours a rich, dark brown with a moderate amount of thick, uneven, taupe/tan head. Produces extensive lacing. Rich, tarry, boozy, vegetal (celery, herbs) taste features cream, licorice, char, prune juice, and chocolate flavors. Alcohol highly noticeable. Flavorful but excessively tarry and boozy. Long, strong, roasted aftertaste. Also a touch of paint flavor in the aftertaste. Creamy and lively in the palate. Warming alcohol effect. A bit of a challenge to imbibe. The beer was very hot; it could have used more aging. It is undeniably good across the board, but it misses the magic of the best of the style. Im kicking myself because I think if I had let this sit in the cellar for a couple of years (as I often let beers do), it might have been really great. As it was, it was disappointing.

Sample @ SBWF 12. Dark almost black colour with a quickly fading brown head with good lacing. Aroma of liquorice, coffee, vanilla. Flavour is roasted chocolate, coffee. Stout like with a medium body. Nice finish. A very nice beer.

Bottle from Salling, Aarhus. Black with a brown head. Aroma is sweet, roasted malt, chocolate, coffee and alcohol. Flavor is quite sweet and very bitter. Dry and roasted rather bitter finish with warming alcohol. Oily. 051012
A very nice roasted flavor with good bitterness. Aroma is roasted and chocolate. Color is black with a creamy head.

Black, with a soapy brown head. Delicious aroma of sweet dark cherry and raisin, whiskey, roast, and molasses. Richly flavored; roasty and fruity sweet with a solid chocolaty bitterness and mild boozy character. Medium-full bodied, dry, smooth and oily. Awesome! Thank you Suttree for the trade!

660 ml bottle - dark brown pour with brown yellowish head. Immediate attack of alcohol warmth :-s. Aromas of nuts, plums, molasse & small bourbon hint. Mouthfeel is fierce warmth and stinginess of the alcohol. Butning from beginning to end. Not my style...
Hadnt had this in quite awhile. And I dont know why- this is a great, big beer! Malty, boozy w/ hints of coffee & roast. Almost more like a stout than American Strong. Love this stuff.

Uploading from Beer Buddy App. Notes from memory. Nice beer. Pitch black. Alcohol flavor was enormous, which turned off people I was sharing the bottle with. This is good if you want something on the more intense end of the spectrum. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Sample on tap at Bières et saveurs (Chambly). Pours black with creamy beige head. Nice lacing. Aroma: torrefied malt, coffee, hops, chocolate, vanilla. Full bodied. Amazing beer!

Pours with quiet viscosity as the label indicates. Aromas of molasses, coffee concentrate and vanilla start things off. The initial mouthfeel is full and round, with a luxuriously creamy texture and smooth finish. Flavors of roasted coffee beans, roasted malt, chocolate, vanilla, raisin, and sarsaparilla repeat in the mouth. While the mouthfeel is full-bodied, it is not overly thick, alcoholic, psweet or sticky. 10% abv is well hidden. Great balance. Well made. Another new favorite. 

--- tasted while on a long journey to understand the world around me...

22 ounce bottle. Opague brown, black liquid topped by a thick, rocky brownish, tan head. Rich, aromatic espresso malt aroma hints at dark chocolate and charcoal. Creamy chocolate malt flavor, bittersweet and roasty. This ale is full of roasted malt flavor that has just a hint of bitter hops. The mouthfeel is chewy and viscuos like its name implies. Sticky like the LaBrea Tarpits. The warming alcohol finish sneaks up on you. This is a great ale for a cold, snowy winter night.

Everyone else provided all the detailed tasting notes so I wont bother talking about the mid-palette lavender aroma balanced with the tarry undertones that transitioned quickly to a sweet toasted hoppy finish...or whatever.   I will add that after spending the last 9 months or so only drinking craft-brew stouts, this is one of my all-time favorites.  A spectacular, big, complex and bold stout-style ale.

On tap @ Chucks 85th.  Pours inky black with thick mocha head that dissipates quickly. Aroma is rich roasty oatmeal malts with faint hops. Taste is oaky dark roasted malts, bitter hops in perfect balance, dark chocolate and a hint of whiskey and vanilla on the finish.  Thick, creamy mouthfeel but only a little thinner than a good stout. The 10% is well-hidden, this drinks easily. Absent some of the big barrel aged porters and stouts, this is head of the class for a strong dark beer. Gotta get my hands on some Older Viscosity next...

Big thanks to GT2. Pours black with a volcanic, explosive head. It literarally soaked my table after the pour. Head sticks around for a bit and leaves great lacing as it goes. Smells boozy and oaky. The texture of this is certainly viscous, as it coats your mouth like syrup and gives great new taste and aroma sensations as you breathe. Taste has sweetness, a lot of boozy and oaky bitterness and some more oak on the following breaths. Theres also some light notes of chocolate and vanilla in this, I guess that runs in line with the sweet/bitter dichotomy. Bomber.
Bottle pours black brown head. Tastes smells of coffee roasty vanilla smile oak. Very solid and tasty beer. Would love it again.

Pours just like they say, used motor oil.  Thick, black, coffee head.  Taste is mild chocolate, lots of roasty malt, a little vanilla and a dry full finish.  Sip and enjoy.

Note...drink warmer, when cold it doesnt have nearly the flavor as when a little warmer.
Pitch black colour with average to huge, firm, frothy to creamy, moderately lacing, beige head. Roasty and slightly smoky aroma, a touch of chocolate and oak.

Location/Date:Bottle spilt with Dave on August 9th, 2012.
Appearance: Pours dark black with light brown head like a porter or stout. 
Aroma: Aroma of roasty malt, faint booziness.
Taste: Roasty, hint of smoke, faint chocolate, light bitterness.
Palate:Medium light body, quick dry finish.
Summary: I really enjoyed this beer even though I have no idea what it really is, but thats truly okay!

7 août 2012 650ml: Très belle couleur noire , avec des reflets orange-brun foncé lorsque la lumière frappe. Mousse abondante, disparraissant asser rapidement laissant un mince collet crème-café. Premiers arômes aux notes légères de café et chocolat, suit des notes de mûres, de dates et même de fraises. Effluves dalcool achèvent le bal. Belle touche de sucrée sans abuser, petite amertume en bouche, bien balancée. Notes de jambon fumée, de tabac. Corps bien établi, texture joliement crémeuse avec un léger croustillant, plutôt faible carbonisation et finale chocolatée, aux notes de guimauves et dalcool. Délicieuse bière difficile à classer, hybdride (imp stout, belgian dark, imp porter, dark barley wine?).

Bottle:
The pour is not even as dark as motoroil, but still looks nice: a dark brown pour which changes like an almost black colored beer with a small tan brown head, in the glass. The head changes slowly into a vast brown lacing.
Smell is very nice: toasted roasted barleys and malts, toffee, caramel, toasted autumnal herbs, some darker sweets (like brown sugar and prune sweetness), cream and roasted barleys.
Taste is nice bitter with loads of barleys, barleys malts, autumnal herbs, toasted herbs, leaves, alcohol, some honey and a lisgt hint of molasses, liquorice, darker and bitter fruits, prunes, raisin, hint of grapefruit, (toasted/roasted) nuts, yeast, spices, some pepper, dry bitter herbs, some dryness and a hint of oatmeal.
Aftertaste is mostly barley malts with all that comes along with barley malts, but the most present in the aftertaste is the caramel and toffee notes, with bitterness, dryness, toasted notes and the autumnal herbs.
Low carbo, soft almost silky mouthfeel, full body and a creamy light oily light sticky texture.
Nice beer, strong but easy drinkable at the same time. Deep but not too complex. (gets better with time).
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: Bottle.  Black with a fairly big light brown head.  Aroma is chocolate, raisins, alcohol, caramel, bourbon, wood.  Taste is medium sweet quite bitter, with lots of wood and roasted flavors.  Finish is very dry and woody.  Very full bodied and smooth, very similar to an imperial stout.
Dark black pour with mocha head.  Oily coffee, american oak, vanilla, chocolate, and whiskey.  Beer to sip while relaxing, like a great whiskey.

650ml bottle. Pitch black colour with average to huge, firm, frothy to creamy, moderately lacing, beige head. Roasty and slightly smoky aroma, a touch of chocolate and oak. Taste is dry, dark malty, roasty, minimally smoky, has some grainy coffee. Oily palate.

Smells like sump oil mixed with fresh roasted coffee beans. Rich and mouth-filling this beer forces the drinker to sit back, sip and savour. Perfect on a winters night with some slow braised lamb shanks or crumbly sharp aged cheddar. YUM!

Almost a 100.
Dark color. Chocolate,coffee,oaks and smokiness.                                        
A very pleasant beer to drink.
Black colour. Taste is coffee and chocolate mixed with some oak and bourbon, and some smokiness as well.
Slight hoppy taste with a strong smokiness too it. Not as full bodied as I expected but overall very good beer

Poured black,  significant light brown head, medium sized bubbles and good lacing. Aromas are great...strong roasted malts with plenty of hops, slight notes of coffee with cherry and citrus. Bitter rotated malt flavors and strong citrus hops followed by a bitter sweet fruityness with toasty undertones and warmth from the alcohol.  Finish; as it warms up the head from the pour settles quit a bit, darker fruit flavors and toastyness comes out...with undertones of wood.

Black pour, thick frothy/creamy tan head sticky lacing .... aroma of roasted/burnt coffee and caramel malts .... taste is of burnt/roasted coffee, bitter dark chocolate, light licorice, light caramel malts and a bitter hop bite on the backend that leads to an oaky dry hopped finish ... roasted bitter and dry oaky brew with the abv hidden very well ... nice tasty brew

A: Black with a beige head, moderate lace.

S: Bourbon, alcohol, roasted malt, cocoa, chocolate.

T: This is an imperial stout. I certainly love imperial stouts, but was expecting something different. Nonetheless, this is a fine brew. A great melding of bourbon and roasted malt. Theres a fair amount of complexity to this one, which I appreciate. ABV hidden well. There is a warming alcohol note in the finish.

M: Smooth. This beer spent almost two years in my cellar, which certainly helped mellow it out a bit. It did maintain a nice carbonation level over that time.

D: I would definitely buy/drink this again.

65 cl bottle @ home. Rated on 24.04.2010
Aroma has some licorice, coffee, woody notes and hints of ash. Flavour has licorice, some sweetish and ripe fruits, hints of ash and wood. Good, like a mixture of Harviestoun Old Engine Oil and Nøgne Ø God Jul. Feels a bit thin for 10% ABV beer though.

Bottle. Coffee & malt on the nose. Beautiful dark black/brown port with tan head and good lacing. The taste is very dark coffee, some chocolate followed by bitterness and some chalk board. Very balanced into a long finish. Nice nightcap.

22 oz bottle. Aged at least a year, and pretty excited to try this. Pours a very dark brown/black color that catches the light in the corners, with a thick light tan head. Smells of bourbon, oak, alcohol, maybe some vanilla; very intense aroma. Taste is much smoother, still with a lot of bourbon and oak flavors, but  very gentle with the alcohol bite lessened. A very full-flavored beer. Very impressive beer, and I would definitely recommend aging it, probably about 3-5 years would be about right.

Bottle
Appearance - Thin, black body, creamy off-white head
Aroma - Oak, mocha, dark fruit
Taste - Cocoa, roasted malts, wood, vanilla, raisins, earthy

This beer was what I expected - a nice and dry brew with quite the oak essence and a satisfying dry finish. Not bad at all!!

Snifter pour at Chipalsas grand tasting. Thanks! Nose is a good amount of chocolate, lots of oak, some ash, and dark fruits. Pour is dark black with a tan head. Taste is a lot of roast, ash, and wood. Again, more chocolate and some slight fruity notes. Bitter finish. A lot of oak notes in this one.
Very fresh taste for 10% alcohol. Green apple, little chocolate. Canidied sugar. A little dry finish.

Pours deep brown&copper with tints of amber and a thick and a solid tan head with intense lacing and retention.
Nose has tonnes of caramel, toffee and oak. Dark fruits in the back, some burnt wood and even more caramel. Subdued pine and grass.
Pine and caramel in the taste giving way to a bittersweet finish with lasting bitterness. Some citrus, more wood and even hints of leather. 
Awesome stuff! Body if full to medium and softly carbonated

650ml bottle. Very dark brown with a monstrous pillowy head. Aroma is weaker than expected with distinct notes of roasted malt and dark chocolate. Predictably thick and viscous with a lovely chocolate fudge sundae taste. Theres even some faint hops in the background. Finishes with powerful bitter roastiness. What struck me the most is how surprisingly drinkable this was, even in a large bottle. It fell slightly short of my high hopes, but I would gladly return to this beer.
thick coffee and alcohol aroma. tons of malt and raisins and fruit and toffee. heavy and chewy, balanced by a bitter chocolate finish and alcohol heat

Excellent beer. Quite similar to a (great) imperial stout. Pours dark brown to black with thick tan head. Aroma is rich and complex, with coffee, cocoa, roasted malt, raisins and dark fruit. Taste is initially bitter before turning into a very sweet long alcohol finish. Body is full and creamy.
Bottle. Very dark pour with a nice creamy head. Big coffee nose. Smooth creamy palate. Taste is bold roasted coffee and chocolate. Excellent.

motor oil black, with tons of beautiful caramel foamy cream head. Nose is boozy, vanilla and oak. Thick body, lots of caramel and roasted flavor. Very dark coffee and dark bitter chocolate favors as well. Quite delicious.
Very dark brown/almost black colour with brown head. Fragrance is rich in hops and coffee and some roasted, oak-like aroma. Taste of roasted coffee. Very good beer.

Pours dark with low white brown head. Low carbonation.
Aromas of dark fruits, some oak, hints of vanilla, chocolate and roasted coffee beans.
Starts out a bit sticky, alcoholly, moves over to a more creamy palate which ends in a very nice bitter fashion. A lot of oak, hoppyness, chocolates in the taste. Not as good as his older brother but still a very good american strong ale!

Poured as dark as dark can get, thicker than thick into my bruery tulip. Two finger head that dissipates into a half finger head that stays the whole drink thru, beautiful lacing, the best Ive seen in a dark stout. Aroma is lighter than expected, coffee, light oak and vanilla. The taste is where this shines, intensified aroma with an amazing coffee finish. This is a thick and chewy beer with carbonation right where it should be. This beer rocks!

Bottle. Pours opaque black with thick, frothy tan head; good retention and lacing. Aroma is roasted and caramel malt, chocolate, figs, earthy hops, and light coffee. Flavor is dark malt dominate with faint supporting hops and dark fruit esters; dry, dark chocolate finish. Medium/full body with medium carbonation and warmth.

Dark brown, almost black with two finger tan head. Aroma is roasted malt, chocolate, carmel, oak, burbon. Taste is coffee, chocolate up front then the back I got more oak barrel and a smokey taste. The coffee hint lingers and surprising not a lot of alcohol burn. Overall very good. Really smooth and complex strong ale. I recommend it.
Bottle. Color dark brown with medium head. Aroma malt, roasted, caramel, chocolate, alcohol, coffee, bourbon. Taste sweet, caramel, chocolate, alcohol, bitter.

Bottle to glass at Joe and Marias in Norwood, MA. delicious aroma. There is nice roastiness as well as some great bittersweet chocolate. Faint bit of coffee.  Dark oily thick pour with moderate off white head. Moderate carbonationand heavy mouthfeel. Nice and oily. Love it.  Really a big fan of this beer.

Bottle. Pours dark black, opaque with a thick, creamy brown head that lasts a long time with good lacing. Aroma is coffee, chocolate. Flavor has coffee, roasted malt, and chocolate notes as well, with significant alchohol notes in the finish. Slightly bitter finish with minimal aftertaste. A bit watery in mouthfeel.

Poured from a bomber into a shaker.  Dark brown color with a foamy tan head.  Aroma is sweet caramel malt, chocolate malt, and some light roasted malts.  Flavor is chocolate, roasted malt, dark fruit, and alcohol. Full bodied with a thick mouthfeel and a somewhat long dry finish.  Overall a very delicious beer.

Fantastic beer. Pitch black with a thin, yet enduring off white head. The nose shows cocoa bean and some dark, plummy fruit. High carbonation creates a balanced mouthfeel. This enters and goes through the mid palate with roasted, imperial stout flavors. This finished with bitter, drying hops. Wild stuff!
Pours a deep black color and a small brown head. Aroma of mocha, chocolate, coffee, and malt. Taste of coffee, chocolate, dark fruits and a nice alcohol burn. Medium to full bodied.

Originally reviewed: 3/8/11. Poured into an Allagash chalice. This beer is aptly named, as this beer pours very thick and viscous. A massive mocha head billows forth. Excellent retention; total coating of the glass edge with lace. The nose is very malty with hints of candy-malt, graham cracker, chocolate powder, and a fresh clean aroma on the finish. The nose is a bit dry, if that makes sense. 

The mouth is full and heavy. Carbonation adds a little bite to it, but this is short and fleeting. This is a way roasted beer. Its bordering on charred and harsh. Theres a fleeting coffee flavor, but its of the burnt variety. Vinous grapes, wine, oak, and alcohol wrap this up. Eh. Its alright, but my hopes were higher going into this.

Botella de 650ml. Copa Globo. Saboreada en dic´11. Color ébano. Espuma beige de burbuja compacta. Corona cremosa con buena retención y collares en las paredes. En nariz notas de cacao y galleta. En boca una increíble sensación de suavidad. El amargor es rápidamente substituido por maltas tostadas que dejan un paladar dulce redondeado por frutos oscuros maduros. Cuerpo pleno y carbonatación suave. Final seco y amargo, seguido por notas de Brandy envejecido. El alto perfil de ABV está bien equilibrado en esta sabrosa cerveza.
22 fl. Oz. bottle. Snifter glass. Enjoyed on dec´11. Ebony color. Beige, small bubbled, froth. Creamy crown with nice retention & collars on sides. Notes of cocoa & biscuit to the nose. Incredible smooth sensation in mouth. Bitterness is quickly substituted by toasted malts leaving such a sweet palate rounded by underliying ripe dark fruits. Full body, soft carbonation. Dry bitter finish followed by notes of aged brandy. High ABV profile is well balanced in this flavorful beer.

Auction Winner. A solid beer from these  guys. 

Nice blend of  big hop, roast, smoke mollasses and spice.

2010 Bottle.  Pour black brown with beige head and good lace. Aroma coffee, brown sugar, molasses, vanilla, chocolate and dark fruit. Taste coffee, roast, toffee, vanilla, chocolate and cocoa powder. . Very bold roastiness.  Nice brew and will gladly purchase each year.

Aroma- dark roast, bittersweet chocolate, expresso.
Appearance- 5000 mile old 10w30 motor oil black with a thick fluffy dark beige head. Long lasting with nice lacing.
Flavor- Nice bitter dark roadted malts, expresso,bittersweet chocolate,some vanilla.

Thanks to alefish for this one. Poured from 22oz bomber to brandy snifter:

Pours without hardly any clarity and a massive, swelling mocha head. Great lacing.

Nose features cocoa nibs, charred wood, molasses, chocolate syrup, alcohol, distant hops.

The taste is pretty heavy on the wood. Dark chocolate, bitter hops, some barrel bits. Pretty well balanced out, a worthy candidate for your beer cellar, I would imagine.

The feel is pretty oily and thick. Give its genre, though, its rather drinkable.

Overall, glad to have had the opportunity to try this and look forward to testing the other bottle after its had some time maturing downstairs.
Bomber. Black pour, foamy coffee head. Coffee, roasted malts, chocolate, licorice, sugars, hints of fruit. Alcohol hidden, medium carbonation, oily, medium-full body.

From a 22 oz  bottle this poured jet black.  Big  tan head. Lots of sticky lacing. Nose  is roasted malts and dark fruit.  Full body. Thick and creamy in the mouth. The flavor are complex and show dark toasted malts, coffee, chocolate, black-strap molasses, and really ripe dark fruit. There is a a good balance between sweetness and bitterness.  The finish is so oily it stays with you. Superb in all respects.
Bottle at Haandverkerstuene. Black colour with a tan head. Aroma is coffe, licorice, malt. Flavour is coffee, licorice, malt, hop, vanilla, chocolate. Very nice beer.

2009 vintage bottle 
Head: large, foamy, espresso 
Colour: very dark brown almost black 
Smell: lost of chocolat , roasted nuts , roasted coffee, salted cashews, bit of booze but not overpowering, bit of sweet soy sauce, candy sugar/sirup, bit of licquorice, this is so rich in fmavour !!! lets hope the flavour is as good otherwise im dissapointed !!! 
Taste: start is buttery caramel, followed by a slight licquorice roasted malty flavour with a tiny bit of blueberrys and booze, then wehn swallowed a bit more anise rises up followed by a bitter slightly yeasty palate, that turns in an earthy bitter dark chocolat, texture is oily , end is semi-dry , aftertaste is grassy , i wanted the flavour to be more like the smell , but nevertheless this is absolutly superb brew !!! now i really want to try it fresh and also the older viscosity i have laying around !!!

Pours blacker than most stouts. Lots of carbonation and a lumpy head that sticks around. Tastes of coffee, chocolate, malt but well blended and balanced. Undercurrent of molasses and breadcrusts. A hint of fruit. Hops seems completely masked. Mouthfeel is not that thick or heavy. ABV also well masked.

Bottles and on tap at brewery. Dark black pour with min head and lacing. Aromas and taste of bourbon, vanilla, peat,butterscotch. Taste is just as good but could be smoother like the aged version older visc. Still great.

Poured into a snifter from a 650ml bottle no date.

A: Pitch black with brown showing through the edges when looked at through a light, thin tan head with little retention.

S: Light oak, vanilla, and bourbon, with a stronger smell of roasted coffee and mocha. This has a rather strong coffee smell and 3 friends said it reminded them of black coffee.

T: Slight mocha up-front into roasted coffee through to the finish. Reminds me a lot of a porter, but turned up a notch.

M: Medium to full-bodied, fresh active carbonation which gets slightly sharp towards the end of the sip.

O: Solid beer, rather intense but a bit one dimensional. I still enjoyed this very much so and think its worth a try.
Pours a jet black with tan head. Nose and taste a deep dark malty bread coffee dark chocolate. Its no Older, but it solid for sure.

Bottle 650ml.
Pours black, with good beige, lacing head. Aroma is of malt, alchool, roasted, smoked. Taste is of brutal hops, ablazed alchool, oak, roasted malt. Long aftertaste, on dry texture. Very hoppy. Very agressive. Oily mouthfeel. Good stuff.
22 oz bomber with Ned555. Midnight black pour with tan lacing.  Roasted malt, chocolate, sugary molasses aroma.  Chocolate, oakey, Molasses, complex.

Opaque black color, large brown head.  Aroma roasted malts, coffee, wood and a little smoke.  Full bodied and somewhat oily, alcohol is not noticable.  Flavors chocolate, nuts, coffee, sweet but balanced well by smokiness and dry finish.  Not really my style, somewhat of a challenge to drink but interesting nonetheless.

Bottle 650 ml [2011]. Pours pitch black with a nice medium brown head. Good lacing. Aroma: Alcohol, smoked, roasted malt, vanilla and wood. Taste: Burning alcohol, hops, wood, roasted malt and a long lasting aftertaste. Texture is oily with a bitter finish that dry the palate. Overall: Very agressive beer but well balanced. Nice one.

A very nice dark beer which does not taste like a 10%. well hidden ABV. Theres nothing very wrong with this beer but im surprised at the 100% rating. Ive liked all the Port Brewing beers so far and this is recommended to try at least once.
Pours pitch black with a tan head. Aroma was coffee and roast. The taste was a nice sweet bourbon flavor, which was quickly replaced wit the heavy dark coffee and chocolate flavors.

Pours blackish brown, sandy persistent head. Aroma of coffee, chocolate, roasted and caramel malts, hazelnut, wood and vanilla on the nose. More of the same on the palate. Rich in carbonation, subtle spiciness in a complex brew.
Aroma of mocha, nuts, and slight vanilla.  Pours black with a huge cotton head.  Tastes of roasty coffee, slight hazelnut.  Delicious and easy to drink.

From notes.  

Old Viscosity pours a motor oil brown color, almost black, with a dollup of mocha froth on top.  The head fades to just a few spots of carbonation on top of the beer.  A surprisingly light transparent edge is also visible when I tilt the glass.

The aroma is full of dark, bitter chocolate and roast, nearly burnt malt.  An oak presence seems to attach itself to every other aroma as well.  There are hints of plums and raisins as it warms.

The flavor is even more controlled by the chocolate and malt notes.  The dark chocolate is pleasantly complex, with a light milk sweetness, a burst of cocoa flavor, a strong bitterness, and a richness only found in good dark chocolate.  The malt has just a touch of smoke, but it is mostly just very fully roasted.  Some coffee grounds add to the bitterness.  Some vanilla, plums, and raisins come in midway through the sip, more so after it has warmed a bit.  A strong woody oak presence comes in toward the end, adding some spice to the finish.  The end is a touch sweet, somewhat spicy, fairly bitter, and noticeably boozy.

The body is on the fuller side of medium for the style, but aside from the alcohol presence it drinks fairly easily.  The creamy carbonation is on the light side.

The oak and alcohol take off significant points from the score.  Although this is an interesting beer, it is nowhere as bewildering as the description on the label would suggest.

A - Pours a dark black-brown color with a finger of frothy chocolate colored head. The head fades down super slowly leaving behind some thick lacing.

S - Aroma is a mix of strong roasted chocolate malts with some oak, coffee, and a nice kick of earthy hops.

T - Starts out with some strong roasted chocolate malts with a bit of coffee and some oak with a touch of sweetness. Through the middle, some earthy hops come through with some bitterness and some more oak with a bit of caramel. The finish is a mix of coffee and chocolate with some earthy hop flavor and a bit of booze coming through.

M - Full bodied with moderate carbonation. Feels smooth and a bit thick and viscous and almost a bit chewy with a warming finish.

D - Very drinkable. Really big and bold but well balanced and it has great complexity to it.

The aroma has a bit of everything, even olives. Yes along with chocolate, vanilla, roast malt, earth and grass, wood. The flavor has all of the aroma and is balanced by a very nice bitterness that gives it a smooth drinkable feel. No alcohol detected despite the 10% ABV. A beautiful black with a larger than expected tan head. A terrific beer.

Deep brown, almost black color with a small white light brown head that leaves little lacing. Smells of dark fruits and roasted malts.Tastes of the roasted malts up front with a dry sweet finish. Bitter chocolate and roasted coffee abound.

Got a 22oz. bomber poured into a snifter. Deep opaque brown with a nice espresso colored head with little retention. Aroma has an acidic quality to it, chocolately and very dry. The flavor mirrors the nose very well. Its a dry chocolate african coffee style flavor. Palate was nice and velvety but a little bit sticky. A little bit dry for my taste, I was almost expecting a deep imperial stout. None the less pretty damn tastey. Cheers
Bottle @ tasting. Aroma is woody, roasted malt, spices, touch of smoke. Nice. Flavour is intense dry roastyness, liquorice, chocolate, its all in there. Great stuff.

Bottle from Csakajosor. Poured black, with a thick, creamy beige foam. Fantastic aroma of honey, licorice, caramel, roasted malts, dark chocolate, espresso, oak, spices. Thick body that is fantastic on the palate with an oily, creamy texture. Roasty, bitter finish with plenty of caramel and molasses. A lot going on with this one, very serious brew. Overall a fantastic one in my book.
Tasting @ De MolenVery dark beer, beige head. Oily texture and soft carbonation. Taste is hints of wood and vanilla, quiet some hops, caramel malts, alcohol.

Very dark brown, surprising medium big beige head. Roasted toast, smoked, dark grapes, burned sugar. Like a creme brule. Tiny bit disappointing. Taste is much more expressive. Alcohol revealed a bit, but still a fairly balanced yet full bodied warming ale. Very smooth, contrasted with a sharpness. Like it, not blow away. (At De Molen tasting)

Bottle at dEnks monthly tasting session @ De Molen. Deep dark brown pour, thin off-white head. Aroma is roasty, spicy, some chocolate and licorice. Flavor is well balanced roasty caramel, fruity and hoppy bitter. Quite American flavor. Nice brew.

Pours an opaque dark brown with creamy light brown head that is small and dissipates relatively quickly leaving no lacing . Medium coffee mild nutty malt aromas with mild citrus and resinous hops.  Starts very briefly as a mild sweet flavor that quickly converts to a medium bitterness.  You can tell it is high alcohol, but it isnt very boozy. Mediumbodied, medium carbonation with surprisingly lively carbonation given how heavy it looks. Very long and bitter finish.  Well balanced mix of malt and hop flavors and hides the ABUs very well.

Csak a jó sör, Budapest.
Tényleg olyan fekete és szinte úgy folyik, mint egy öreg autóból kifolyó, kissé megégett, fáradt olaj. Habja igen vékony, világos barna és végig megmarad, mint egy használt szemfedő. Illata kávélikőrös, fekete csokis, vaníliás és kissé nehéz. Ízében is a kávés jegyek dominálnak, pörkölt magvas ízekkel, kakaóval, konyakkal, komlós gyantássággal, egész összecsavarja a nyelvünket. Nehéz, sűrű teste van, amiben nem érezni annyira a buborékokat, de az alkoholtartalmat annál inkább. Utóíze olyan, mintha neszkávéból kapnánk az ír kávét, keserédes, likőrös a vége pedig nagyon száraz. Kizárólag erős nyelvbimbókkal rendelkezőknek és csakis lassan kortyolva ajánlott!

Received in trade from P1Meatloaf. Review copied from notes.
Pours a very think black with a creamy, tan head.
Smells of rich chocolate malts with a slight alcohol presence.
Tastes of chocolate, caramel, and nice faint bourbon from the barrels.
A very good beer.

Pours a dark ruby almost black. Aromas of caramel, cocoa, roasted malt and vanilla. Very pleasant. First taste is alcohol with charredness, smoky, cocoa and burnt. Follows with a very bitter hoppy burnt flavor. But not bad. Definitely different. Mouthfeel is slightly oily. Overall a delicious beer and definitely different.

Served in the DFH snifter, I shared this liquid gold with a new "in Person" trader, Morey (See below). The beer pours dark brown/black with an inch of a creamy tan head which stays around for a while. Theres also a decent amount of lacing. Aroma is sweet and malty, it smells like chocolate, molasses, roasted and burnt/charred malt, vanilla, and maybe some oak. The smell is actually kinda light, but enough to make out the wonderful character. The brew tastes like bittersweet chocolate, coffee, anise, vanilla, oak, molasses, and some burnt/charred malt. Theres also a nice roasty bitter finish. As it warms, the ABV presents its self...In a good way. Mouth feel is medium/full, its nice and creamy and coating with good carbonation. 1 site says Imperial Stout, the other says American Strong Ale. I would definitely say.... Imperial Stout. Now to land the Older Viscosity.

Pour cola black brown with beige/tan head good lace. Aroma coffee, maple, brown sugar, molasses, vanilla, bourbon, dark fruit. Taste coffee, roast, toffee, brown sugar, light dark fruit, vanilla, wood, oak, chocolate, cocoa powder. MF full body mild carb. Very tasty big roastiness of a RIS but not very pleasing to palate.

Bottle at Brewdog Edinburgh. Pours black with a foamy tan head. The nose reveals a bourbon smoke edge, backed up be some vanilla-y, creamy, raisiny notes. The flavours are more figgy, chocolate, vanilla, hazelnut and something which seemed like pecan. Too much carbonation for my liking, though, I have to say.

Bottle at BrewDog. Inky black viscous (surprise...) pour, thick foamy tan head that slowly fades. Massive nose, hint of Bourbon, thick chocolate, vanilla, slight raisin/plummy fruit. Smooth sweet palate, massive dark chocolate, vanilla, mocha, lots of booze, petrol, slight fig, bitter puckering coffee & smoke finish. Over-fizzy. Not bad, slightly unbalanced but still good.

Its like motor oil.  But you can drink it. 

People who hate this beer are big girls blouses.

65 cl bottle.
Rated on 20100424.
Nice black color with small head. Aroma has liquorice, ripe fruits and caramel malts. Flavor of liquorice, caramel, fruits and some chocolate. Nice oily texture.
Pours black with a large mocha head. Aroma is coffee grinds. Flavor is burnt malt with a hoppy finish. . Has a touch of heat.
Bottle shared with beerboxer. Good dark malt. Slightly hoppy. Great for a oak barrel aged beer
Bottled sample at beer bistro. Amer strong ale is becoming one of my favourite styles.  This beer packa a punch, Caused me to doze off at the Leafs game

Opaque black with a tan head.Foamy-creamy- heady and good lacing.
 Aroma of chocolate mildly malty with some yeast and or breadiness.
iNitial creamy mouthfeel smooth then a good amount of carbonationg giving it a sharp bright feel some malt/alcohol chocolate and coffee with a hard hitting strong bittering with underlieing sweetness of dark fruit, lots of robust herbal bittering,with dry bourbony? woody notes. Vanilla tones lingeri ng coffee presence.Great example of a strong ale

650 ml bottle @ Haandtverkerstuene. Black body with a moderate beige head. Strong aroma of dark malt, vanilla, roast, coffee and some liquorices and warming alcohol. Flavor is sweet, roasted malt, bitter, fruity, coffee, wood and warming alcohol. Full body and long aftertaste. A nice and strong beer with a long and warming aftertaste.

On tap at the Pourhouse in Westmont, NJ.  Pours a silky ribbon of liquid ebony with a short dark brown head.  Curtains of lacing that would make the Kodak Theater in Hollywood proud.  Aroma of freshly brewed coffee, bittersweet chocolate and a hint of smoke.  Rich, complex flavor profile with dark fruits, raisins, cocoa, caramel, vanilla, coffee and roasted malt.  Wonderfully rich texture and a long, mildly sweet, mildly warming finish.  Another world-class brew from Tomme Arthur.
Black with a tan head. Aroma is coffee, chocolate, vanilla. Oily mouthfeel, slightly bitter finish. Taste is coffee, soy sauce, oak, licorice.

[place holder rating- notes backlog] Essentially one of my favorite beers of all time and one of the first beers ever that blew me away. It is now a cellar staple and a great semi-smoky imperial stout of sorts I cannot get enough of.
Pours just like the name, super thick.  Nice creamy tan head.  Potent coffee taste with a hoppy finish.  Very good!  Definitely will drink again.

Very dark pour. Aroma is sweet licorice. Taste is bold with much attitude. Very hoppy yet intense with flavor. Hope to try this again soon. It was served a bit cold. I imagine this will be better if warmer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Off white Soft head, deep brown, almost black body. Aroma of oak, roasted malt, flavor is very salty, like an old ale. Meaty. Not too hoppy, but bitterness is earthy and roasty. Shared at Curtiss (Nashvilles Sweetwarer Representative) tasting.
Bottle. Dark brown, tan head. Smells toasty, smokey. Rich, smokey, slight coffee. Creamy, bitter aftertaste. Yummy, definitely will get again!

Bottle. Pours a dark brown color with a nice 2 finger tan head. Good retention. Nice roast note in the nose with a sligth touch of the barrels. Medium mouthfeel. Nice lace. Dark roast, caramel, slight vanilla, and some dark fruit notes round out the flavor. Ends slightly dry with a slght lingering bitterness. Smooth and silky. Nice.

Bottle. Pours a viscous opaque black with a beautiful tan head. Smells of raisin, vanilla, bourbon and other deliciousness. Tastes creamy with roasted coffee and malt presenting a strong bitterness with a mild bourbony sweetness that follows. Carbonation is soft. Texture is creamy.  Finishes bitter. Very good, but definitely a different beer from the Older.

Tasted on 8/18/11 from a 22oz bomber bottle purchased at Lush Roscoe, bottled on 3/31/10.  Pours opaque black with an average tan head that slowly recedes to a thin layer of uneven lace.  The nose is very malty and roasted with dark chocolate, coffee, molasses, fig, and light vanilla.  The flavor is the same with some more dark chocolate and coffee and the sweeter molasses, fig, and milk chocolate flavors underlying.  The body is full with lively carbonation and a long dark chocolate and coffee finish, and a bit of alcoholic heat.

22oz into sniffer. Aroma is prunes raisens chocolate boozy caramel. The pour is amazingly sexy. Yuuuup sexy. Light tan somewhat lasting thick head. Taste is dark chocolate bitterness some booze some coffee some wood. Overall very good. Even though u get some hints of booze it really doesnt feel like  a 10% beer. Think because its balanced well and has that oaky finish. Not heavy on the palate or sticky. Good stuff for Xmas!
Tasting in Athens, Nov.09. Opaque black with a medium, lacing brown head. Aroma of chocolate, roasted malt, vanilla. Roasted malty taste  with coffee, caramel, vanilla and chocolate finish.
Black with a dark brown head - sweet dark malt aroma - same sweet malt taste with some roast and cofee with some hints of alcohol in the back - this was very nice

Bottle from Mane Liquor. Pours a hugely dark brown, almost black, with dark red hues on the edges. A big fluffy lightly tanned head is produced which takes some time to come down. Quite boozy on the nose. Chocolatey undertones with roasted malts and a nice touch of liquorice. Quite woody with a hint of whiskey tones. Heavy cocoa and wood in the taste with bitter mocha like flavours on the finish. Barely any booze in the taste. Pretty impressive beer. Not amazing but I would be willing to have this again

For my 453rd rating an eagerly anticipated drink.  Courtesy of Ernesto987.  Poured from a bomber into a pint glass or 2.  Poured a very dark brown viscous! liquid with billowy beige head.  Aroma is toast, light fruitiness, chocolate, and spice.  Taste is medium sweetness with a good bitter finish and loads of dark malt flavors.  Good stuff.

Bottle pours chestnut brown with minimal head.  Aromas are malty, sweet and cocoa.  The taste is chocolate, caramel, bitterness, and some marshmallow.  Overall, a very good beer that is not too boozy.  Nice job on this one

UPDATED: DEC 19, 2011 Shared bottle in summer 2011 @ Bishops Arms in Örebro.
Explosions in the mouth. Not enough superlatives to describe it.
This is pretty much as good as it gets.

Wow. Pours black with a dense and thick dark beige head. Aroma is chocolate, coffee, creamy, some vanilla, alcohol, an ever so subtle hint of banana and just a bit chalky. Taste is dark chocolate, coffee, alcohol a little dark fruit. This thick and oily elixir sticks with the mouth and coats the throat. Really nice; cant wait to try the "Older" version as well.

This is always special when I drink this, I wait for special conditions for this beer.  Tonight is cold and rainy, perfect for a Older Viscosity,  Chocolate and alcohol nose and of course bourbon,  Great palate.  The flavors are wonderful, bourbon with some smokeyness, along with a dryness in the finish,  I like it being not to sweet in the taste.

650ml bottle. Near black pour with red/brown highlights. Huge rocky tan head that leaves a ton of lace. Nose of caramel and brown sugar. Brandy and hops as well. Fairly hoppy with a good robust feel and a finish that lasts forever.

Darkbeer red colour.
Wet wood. prune. oak. smoke but welcoming. toast and balance. big flavour. awsome

650ml bottle pours almost black in color with 2 fingers of beige head which left behind some nice lacing.  Aroma is mild whiskey with light roasted malt.  Taste is malty sweet with a bit of whiskey and a moderate hoppy bitter finish.  Heavy body and mild carbonation provide a decent mouthfeel.  A very nicely balanced brew with an undisclosed beer style.  Strong Ale is as good as any to describe this one.

UPDATED: NOV 22, 2011 Tout dabord en louvrant...POP!!...Pas le problème de la bière morte, beaucoup deffervescence avec un épais mais délicat collet. Pas aussi collant et sirupeux que je lavais anticipé, au contraire, très balancé avec une présence en bouche moyenne. Beaucoup de chocolat, vanille, whiskey avec le bois qui pique le bout de la langue. Une toute autre bête de ce à quoi je mattendais. Lénorme dépôt au fond mencourage à garder lautre bouteille pour beaucoup plus tard.

UPDATED: NOV 21, 2011 15/11/2011 1Pt. 6Fl. Oz. bottle @ Klaas place - bottled: ?/2011 (smudged ink)  (2011-644) Thanks to Klaas for sharing the bottle!
Clear very dark brown beer, creamy beige head, unstable, adhesive. Aroma: dried fruits, ripe banana, rotten banana peel, mocha, dark caramel. Mf: quite some carbon, medium to full body. Taste: bit sour start, fruity (plums), mocha and coffee, bitter chocolate. Aftertaste: coffee, bitter hops, hoppy dryness, traces of liquorice.

black/browinsh color. Aromas of dark malt, a little bit of oak, very subtle. Medium body and easy to drink. A little bit of sweetness, alcohol hidden well.  I feel like its restricted and would like to revisit this again next year after aging to see if it opens up. Nice beer but not what I was expecting and I am a little bit disappointed.

Bottle at DØE tasting.
