Black with a brown head. Aroma heavy malty (roasted, burnt, dark chocolate), light hoppy. Flavor moderate sweet (barrel, vinous, smoky) and hoppy, long lasting. Fat body, some alcohol. Very nice indeed.

14.10.2011. At Haandverkerstuene. Thanks Beer2000. Very rich beer. Aromas of dark malts. Dry mouthfeel with some chocolate flavours. Very strong with lots of alcohol and malt. There is also some notes of red fruits.

Dark pour, large frothy head that lingers a while.  Earthy, malty aroma with definite oakiness to it.  There is also hint of fruit, reminding me of freshly picked strawberries.  Strong burnt-malt flavor as it hits your tongue, that turns into a burn caramel that lasts a while.  There is an interesting disconnect between the aroma and the flavor, but I really like it.
Dark brown with a small tan head. Malty with fruity tones. Malt, coffee and oak. Full body with a bitter-sweet after taste.
Bottle from 2009. Very dark brown colour with a pale brown head. Malty, roasted and sweet. Licorice, caramel, tar, chocolate. Smooth and full bodied. Very nice.

Pours near black. Slight mocha head and a slight amount of lacing. The nose is loaded with coffee, chocolate, vanilla, roast, and a bit of anise. The taste i most coffee and chocolate alongside the roast, and the balance is great. Good feel with a nice body and alcohol level.

22 ounce bottle, bottled on 4/25/2011.  Served in a snifter, the beer pours dark brown/black with an inch and a half frothy tan head which stays around for a while.  Theres also a decent amount of lacing.  Aroma is sweet and malty, it smells like chocolate, molasses, roasted and burnt/charred malt, vanilla, and some oak and coffee.  The brew tastes like bittersweet chocolate, coffee, anise, vanilla, oak, molasses, and some burnt/charred malt.  Theres also a nice roasty bitter finish.  Mouthfeel/body is medium/full, its a bit creamy and coating with good carbonation.  I liked this beer a lot.  And at $7.99 a bomber, Id buy this again the next time I see it.  Definitely worth trying.

Dark brown color with a big brown head. Aroma of dark fruits, licorice, raisin, smoke, and vanila. Taste of medium sweetness, lightly sour, medium body, slick feel, average carbonation, finish is a little warming. Pretty good and drinkable for 10%.

I dug around for a flashlight and  cast light into the tulip glass I filled with the beer... pitch black; I couldnt see to the other side. The taste is so delicious with flavors of chocolate and a little bit of licorice. The big surprise is a generous amount of carbonation which remains hidden under the blackness of this beer... it complements the beverage well, but may be a bit of a surprise to the uninitiated. I cant think of a much greater beer than this for the price. For an even more intense experience, try Older Viscosity, where the flavor increases tenfold. I would place this beer somewhere between "youve got to really try this" to "why havent you gone to the liquor store right now?!".

Bottle 660ml @ Håndverkerstuene, Oslo
[Courtesy of Beer2000] Pours dark brown with a light tan head. Aroma has notes of malt, licorice, vanilla and oak. Taste is medium to heavy sweet of chocolate, vanilla, oak, earthy, leather, alcohol and light bitter with a long chocolate warm finish. Body is full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

Pours hazy dark reddish brown with nice tan head, aroma has notes of toffee, caramel, vanilla, molasses, nice dry oak, hints of cola and slight earth and spice.  Taste is nice oak, toffee, caramel, cola, molasses, vanilla, some slight bitter earth, finishing bitter and dry.  Really nicely done.

Bottle from Beers of Europe. Very dark brown colour, beige head. Nose is slight roasted malts, coffee, nutty, some fruits. Flavour is slightly sweet malted, roastiness, coffee, sour fruits, raisins. Little boozy finish.

Bottle. Pours deep brown, cola black with tan head. Decent hops, choc brown malt , caramel biscuit sweet mocha. Full-med body choc caramel biscuits generous hop flav & balanced bitterness. Sweet reflective finish.

Bottle. Very dark brown with a large tan head. Aroma of dark and burnt toffee, licorice, dried fruit, whiskey, oak, coffee. Overcarbonated at first, mouthfeel yields to oily after a fair while. Taste has lots of coffee and bittersweet chocolate, licorice, spices. Woody and bitter finish with some salt. A bit shouty and boozy where it needs to inveigle.

65cl bottle at Håndverkerstuene. Thanks beer2000. Very dark brown colour with a very small head. Aroma is nuts, coffee, sweet malts and some liqorice. Flavour is bitter, but in a good way. Liqorice is the first impression but coffee, malts and alcohol soon makes themselves known as well. Long lingering aftertaste and the acohol gives a warming feeling in the back of the mouth for a long time.

A dark, chocolate-brown pour with a light brown head.  It has the sugary aroma of  a blowpop sucker mixed with a woody quality.  The full body has a thick and creamy texture with average carbonation.  The taste is sweet up front and has a mouthwatering, slightly bitter finish.

Bottle, courtesy of Beer2000. Pours dark amber with a beige head. Aroma of malt, caramel, hay, biscuits and yeast. Flavor is sweet and malty with some warming caramel, spicy notes, grains and toasted grains. Full body, soft carbonation. Nice

Pours a a completely opaque dark brown with a full tan head.  Mild espresso aroma.  Taste is very busy with everything youd expect in a dark high ABV brew.  Lets see, coffee (espresso), bitter dark unsweetened chocolate, molasses and even a bit of a vinous character (Merlot?).  Quite good, and the high alcohol is not particularly evident.

Pours dark brown/black color with tan head. Roasted malt and chocolate aromas with some booziness. Sweet milk chocolate flavor with roasted malts and some bitterness. Slightly boozy. Medium to full body with moderate carbonation. Very nice.

Dark brown body with an off white head. Strong malty aroma, with alcohol, honey, licorice, spices, some cherries and a bitter tone. Full complex flavor with wood, alcohol, some coffee, burned malts, a strong hoppy tone, some chocolate as well. This is excellent.

Nose is coffee, cocoa, velvet malt, weak iron, late earth with a surprisingly potent hops note, alcohol is extremely subtle, feel is quite broad, carb is mediumlow, taste is medium roasted malt, bitter chocolate, heavily understated alcohol, rotten fruit, balanced hops finish

Dark and brown with a huge foamy tan head. Very roasty-toasty with malty thickness. Strong body with a very bold and strong finish. Hints of raisin and light spice. The hops are there, but not at the forefront. Nice to savor.

Dark brown/black color; Medium to heavy creamy body; Aroma of toasted malt, caramel, some dark fruit, & spice; Flavor of roasted malt, oak, caramel, dark chocolate, coffee, spicy hops, and some licorice; Finish is slightly bitter; Nicely balanced; Overall, different and very stout like - I enjoyed it.

Aroma- muted chocolate, malt, roast, caramel
Appearance- pours relatively black with brown hues, huge head and nice lacing
Taste- complex but hard to describe, getting hints of imperial stout qualities, but more comparable to a porter
Palate- relatively full, carbonation cuts sweetness nicely
Overall- A baffling beer for me.  It looks, smells, and partially drinks like a stout/porter but everything is relatively muted.  Could have been something special but a let-down in my book.

Sampled at Gothenburg Beer Festival 2011. September 3, 2011

Rich aromas of bourbon, chocolate and molasses. It feels very smooth and balanced. The body is much lighter than the aroma suggests but it still got a good amount of bourbon and chocolate. This really resembles a good imperial stout!

22 ounce bottle that poured a dark brown sludge.  Aromas of bourbon stings the nostrils, but in a good way.  Also malt, chocolate,  molassas, and coffee aromas can be detected.  Flavors follow the aroma, but the bourbon flavors are not as overpowering as the aroma would make you think.

UPDATED: FEB 1, 2014 Bottle, sample. Have been looking forward to trying this one, since I love Older Viscosity. Dark brown with a porous tan head. Aroma: licorice, wine gums, chocolate, malty, roasted and creamy. Taste: chocolate, licorice, coffee, malty, a bit dryish. Pretty full-bodied, smooth. Very nice.

Poured a dark, dark brown with a coffee-colored head. Thick liquid with some carbonation for texture. Bourbon, malt, molasses, dark fruit, and chocolate. The aroma struck me as soon as the bottle was opened. Tied with the Older for best Port Brew Ive had.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 A: dark black/brown body.. khaki head... lasts for a while before giving way to thick lacing on the glass

S: All things dark... chocolate, coffee, licorice, molases and boubron... with hints of oak and vanilla...

T: Mirroring the nose, this beer is rich... nice roasted malts give the chocolate, coffee, licorice and molases notes... excellent barrel aged bourbon/vanilla/oak flavors are imparted here too

M: Viscous... just like the name suggests... thick creamy smooth body... nice slighlty oily finish

(bottle 10/26/10). Black color. Large brown head. Moderate roasted malt aroma with light chocolate. Flavor of the same with dark chocolate character. Avg duration. Light bitter finish. Slick texture. Moderate carbonation. Good lacing.

22oz bottle.
Dark brown pour with a decent amount of creamy tan head.  Aromas of bourbon and lots of malt - flavors of chocolate, roasted malt, and wood.
Lots of head and lots of wood with this. Easy to drink and one of the better beers to come out of Port Brewing in a big way.

A beer drinkers beer.  Pours a sultry, thick mud brown with thick and chocolate head a with legs and lace.  Nose thick with chewy raisin and molasses.  Thick mouthfeel with lateral sour bite as a caramel, raisin, and fruit cake move down the middle leaving a bitter, biting, alcohol finish.
Very dark brown. Almost black at the glass. Almost no head, costs points ofcourse. Wooden, liqourish warming, caramel, dark fruits. Sweet, a bit siropy.

Bottle shared by zinister at the Houston May 2011 tasting. Pours a dark brown with small light tan head with spotty lacing. Aroma is chocolate coffee and oak. thin mouthfeel with a sweet malt and coffee with alcohol present but not overpowering. A very good American strong ale from Port Brewing.

on tap @ bar eleven in SD. Big, luscious flavors of dried fruits, molasses, and bourbon with a nice boozy flavor and aroma to it. Thick, almost chewy beer. One of the best palates Ive had on a beer in a long time. Great beer.

Im Geruch gewöhnungsbedürftige stark röstige, verbrannt wirkende Malzaromen. Etwas süßlich, medizinisch anmutender Start. Anschließend schokoladig einsetzend und scharf alkoholisch bis in den Schluß. Hier dann, Gott sein Dank, noch versöhnlich wirkende Toffeenoten, welche dem Alkohol halbwegs die Stirn bieten. 
Nicht gerade ein umwerfendes Bier.Test vom 6.11.2010, Gebinde: Glasflasche

Bottle from binnys on Marcey. Pours a deep brown black with a billowy tan froth. Nose is hopper than expected with char and roast. Some light vanilla and cocoa. Not overly roasty though. On taste bitter and char dominate, light cocoa and vanilla notes. A bit thin bodied and over carbonated. Older viscosity is far superior, though this aint horrible.

Pours  dark brown with a significant head for such a dark beer.  The head craters slowly as it goes down and the beer is dark and dense enough in the glass that you cant see through it.  Aromas of dark fruit, chocolate and coffee.  Flavor is rich and sweet.  Creamy chocolate with ripe cherries and just a hint of alcohol.  Thick and creamy in the mouth with very tiny bubbles.  This beer is comparable to an imperial stout.  A very good beer, but slightly sweeter than I would have liked.

Bottle pours thick brown-black with thick and persistent tan head.  Aroma mainly dark fruits.  Taste roasted malts, a bit of chocolate and coffee, dark fruits.  Mild but long finish of coffee and roast.  Palate a bit of a letdown, on the thin side with moderate carbonation.  Didnt appreciate much alcohol.  
I probably made a mistake having the Older Viscosity before this one as it suffers a little in comparison.  Still a decent beer.
Scura, intenso aroma di fruttato, complesso, a metà strada tra una belgian e una porter, ma con una bella dose di luppolo. Bella complessa!
Black of color with a reddish hint and beige head. An aroma of liqurice, prunes and spice. A flavor of liqurice, sweet notes, roasted malt, weak prunes and weak hops.
Very good overall. Lots of smells when the beer is poured, mostly of a raisin nature. There is dark fruit flavor that is similar to a porter or a stout. It goes down smooth and lingers a long time.

Bottle shared at Øl og matfestivalen.
Dark brown, almost black, thick creamy tanned head.
Burned roasty aroma, dark fruits, coffee, chocolate, this is really great!
Taste is also roasty with wood, vanilla, coffee, fruits, taste explotion. 
Good body and a long lasting bitter coffee finish. 
A remarkable enjoyable beer

Bottle poured into snifter glass. Very dark color with a big fluffy head. Good carbonation and lacing. Aroma has sweet, oaky, woody characters while the flavor has a bitter start with a sweet finish. Malt abounds in the flavor with hints of maple and bourbon. Flavors mask the ABV very well here.

[Bottle] Clouded dark brown appearance, thick enduring beige foam. Dark roasted chocolate malt aroma, hints of raisin, coffee and licorice, some citrussy hops.Creamy bourbon, vanilla palate - chocolate, coffee and citrussy grapefruit finish, noticeable alcohol. There are some big bold flavors here but it all seems to blend in well together.

220z bottle.  Pours completely opaque with a bubbly tan head that is quick to run and hide but leaves a patchy oily film.  Nose is chocolate followed by roast malt, vanilla, spice, and alcohol.  Very malty on the tongue but with an earthy bitterness that doesnt balance well.  Surprisingly carbonated finish with lingering aftertaste of burnt wood and booze.

Savannah, Ga - Habersham Beverage Warehouse - 22 oz bomber. Dark purple almost black pour with a sticky, frothy khaki colored head that lasts the entire pour. Nutty, fruit forward aroma with brief hints of spruce and pomegranates. Flavor is sweet and strong. Nice caramel sweetness, hints of grapefruity bitterness, a touch of port, some hints of chocolate. Thick, sticky mouthfeel. Would make an excellent winter belly warmer.  All around, solid.

Bottle from Beermerchants.com. Pours almost pitch black with a big nice looking creamy tanned head. Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate and some hops. Smooth mouthfeel. Taste is dark roasted, and lots of hops working together, creating a wonderful moderate bitter brew, good amounts of coffee as well. Full bodied. Good bitter aftertaste, lingering and dry finish.

Bomber, 1 year aged at home. Aroma of vanilla, oak. Rather woody, somewhat roasty, dark fruits. Flavors of root beer, wood, licorice and caramel, some cocoa, alcohol, blueberries. A bit roasty. Great balance, nice fruit, good bitterness. Enjoyable stuff.

Sigh.yet another legendary beer that has failed to live up to my expectations, but this might have been cellared to long (13 months, properly). First off got to say, American strong ale? Really? This has Porter written all over it. Ok time to stop bitching and on to the review.  Dark dark brown with an ok cap, this is not what I was expecting. Aroma is almost nonexistent, what the hell?!?!? This beer is smellless!! Ill let it warm more I guess. Five waiting units later.. Aroma has appeared and its not great, cold coffee, weak bakers chocolate, some random harshness, I sometimes get woody alcohol. I taste some of the oak ageing but not to confidant in saying that, ash, cold coffee, wet dirt, and mild alcohol I do taste. Nameless hops can be tasted along with a random spice. Im so disappointed in this beer so my marks are probably lower than they should be. Why do I let myself get hurt like this?

Thx Brad. Bought 13 months ago. This is really dark - how dark? I stopped caring. Good thick light brown cap and plenty of lacing. Not a big fan of the aroma at this point - too much coffee is annoying and Im not down. Wood alcohol on deep sniffs, faint hops, some harshness, weak chocolate, the coffee is cold and icky. Unfortunately this reminds me of a typical American Porter. Also has that spice / alcohol aroma and some smooth chocolate. Ok taste.. better than I have been giving it credit for as there is enough quiet complexity. Spice and breathable alcohol notes, caramel, anise, astringent, coffee, more hard spices that really dig into my taste buds and roof of my mouth. Dulled coffee and a bit of sweetness fail at keeping the spice away. A little rough around the edges. Fairly smooth.
Sampled blind at Blue Palms Ultimate Brown Bag event.  Pours a dark brown with some really big bourbon notes right off the bat.  Coffee notes in their as well.  Simple and direct.

Poured from 22oz (bottled 4-25-11) into a wide-bottomed snifter.  Pours black with brownish red edges and a thick, tan head with incredible retention.  Aroma is chocolate. BIG chocolate. Notes of biscuit, ethanol, leather, and oak are present as well, tons of complexity in this one.  Taste reminds me of leather and tobacco smoke against a bitter dark chocolate backdrop.  Pairs well with my almond, cashew, and bittersweet chocolate trail mix.  Body is medium with average carbonation.  As far as Im concerned, the flavor of this brew is remarkable but it lacks the chewy body that I crave in a chocolate-forward brew.  This beer is somewhere between an imperial porter and an imperial stout.  Overall, it is very good beer and I have rated it as such, but it is a bit unbalanced (too bitter) in its youth and would certainly benefit immensely from a year or two in the cellar.

Aroma: heavily roaste, chocolate, coffee, ashy, alcohol.
Appearance: pitch black
Flavour: rich, coffee, chocolate, sugary, dar fruits. 
Mouthfeel: thick.
Total: very rich, yet smooth.
Bottle shared. Dark, thick brown head. Smells of coffee, chocolate and roasted malts. Taste of liquorice, salt and hints of malts. Nice sweetness. Feel is quite oily, Good bitter finish
Bottle pours a cloudy dark brown with a thick off white head. Scent is roasty with notes of chocolate, booze and wood. Taste is roasty as well with boubon, hops and a bit of salt. Very good!

22 oz. bottle. Pours black with a huge, foamy, beige head. The aroma is figs, apples, licorice, molasses and coffee. The flavor is very sweet with a sour finish. The palate is very heavy, creamy, and acidic with a significant alcohol warming. Overall, a very strong, flavorful and complex beer.

Poured from a 22oz bomber. Colour is nice black, with thick tan creamy head. Lots of lacing down the glass. Aroma is very alchoholy. Some malt on the nose, flavour is bitter up front, followed by smokey roasty flavours, some chocolate, and coffee taste. The finish is long and dry. Very smooth for the abv.

Cant decide what this beer is.  I guess strong ale is a good way to describe.  It starts out like a porter and ends like a stout but has enough hops to kick your butt.  Looks great and tastes great if you can handle it.  I could probably only hndle one of these.

22oz into tumbler.  2 finger brown lovely head.  virtually black look.  smells of chocolate coffee malt smell with a hint of alc.  smooth semi thick deep chocolate taste at first followed by coffee and some slight bitterness then the barrel aged twang hits and rides it to a smooth finish.  also some spices in the taste along with caramel.  delicious beer.  I would define it more as a imperial stout instead of American Strong Ale.  overall 9 of 10
Pours a very dark brown with allmost no head. Aroma is caramel, overripe dark fruits, chocolate, spice and pepper. Taste is liquorce, vanilla, light bourbon, coconut and some caramel.

Bottle, 66 cl. Deep red brown, not much head. Aroma has chocolate, vanilla, motor oil, spices, chili, toffee, alcohol. Taste has alcohol, charcoal, roast, alcohol, coconut, not very balanced. Almost as disappointing as Older Viscosity.

Shared bottle at Cardinal. Murky mahogany verging on black with a creamy, fingerthick, light brown head. Roasted barley, toffee, coffee aroma with a hint of smoke. Roasted, bitter, sweet and alcoholic flavors. Full body. Syrupy/oily. Rich carbonation.

sure is viscous. sweet drowning in caramel followed by assault of heavy bitterness followed by a finish that is more a physical oil slick on the tongue than an actual flavour. toasty and chocolatey short of bitter roast, but still would easily qualify as a stout anywhere except the US. some quality fruity-malty complexity saves this from being just another extreme beer.

22ozer poured into snifter.  Deep, dark brown in color with black and burnt red highlights...not quite opaque black.  Thick, extremely frothy cappuccino brown colored head.  Insane lacing.  Excellent nose full of dark roasted malt, chocolate covered biscuits, slight coffee, and a burst of earthy hops.  Wow...taste blast!  Full of more elements from the nose, roasty, bitter malt, coffee, chocolate, etc.  Hints of leather, booze, and caramel too.  Thick and oily on the tongue with a very bitter, lingering finish.  Fantastic well balanced, complex beer.
Bottle pours black with a brown head.  Aroma shows notes of dark chocolate, roasted malt, caramel, and vanilla.  Flavor shows the same with additional notes of licorice, molasses, and a touch of tar.
thick retaining head, aroma if of complex malts, tarty bitterish fresh flavor, smooth, the flavor is very different from the nose. Delicious

Bomber via thome50.  I wasnt expecting this to be too carbonated when I poured this, so I gave it a rather aggressive pour.  Well I was completely wrong.  Pour is deep, dark brown with a large pillowy khaki head.  Nice roasty aroma with coffee and chocolate.  Taste is sweet toffee, light vanilla, with a hint of roasted coffee and chocolate towards the finish.  Medium body and loads of lacing left on the glass.  Very nice beer.  Thanks Justin.

Bomber from 2009. Pour an opaque black, head is almost non-existent, nice brown lacing. Smells of malt, anise, and bourbon but not overpowering. Nice strong taste, sweet at first from the bourbon, changes to a nice bitterness throughout the finish. Roasted malts are present from start to finish, get a bit of toffee, chocolate more bourbon. Very good beer - cant remember what it was like fresh but the taste is much stronger then the aroma or finish - need to try this one on tap.

Reviewed from notes.

Pours near black. Slight mocha head and a slight amount of lacing. The nose is loaded with coffee, chocolate, vanilla, roast, and a bit of anise. The taste i most coffee and chocolate alongside the roast, and the balance is great. Good feel with a nice body and alcohol level. Drinks very well and is another hit from Port.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-03-2010

Rich aroma has smoky tones of roast quality coffee, semi-sweet chocolate, caramel and molasses with just a touch of sweetness. It absolutely screams DRINK ME!!! Comes out of the bottle a nearly opaque reddish sable just a couple tomcat whiskers above black with a thick, fluffy, fine-bubbled light beige head. Flavor is - um, you sure this is an American Strong Ale and not a porter or stout? I LOVE stouts and porters, and this sure tastes like one! OK - mouth-filling flavor has tones of semi-sweet chocolate, quality coffee, caramel and licorice with a subtle hint of citrus. Texture is fizzy and lively, leaving behind a firm and pleasant tingle. This just might be Port Brewings best, outside of the Lost Abbey series!

Bouteille de 650ml. Merci Slovak Sniper. Cette bière est noire, la mousse est rocailleuse, épaisse, durable, beige foncée, des particules collent au parois. Il est difficile de faire mieux. Le nez est riche, il remplit les narines deffluves de cassonade, de grains grillés, de mélasse, de vanille provenant du chêne, de piloncillo et de panela. La bouche est onctueuse, huileuse, le ptit Jésus sent lhuile à transmission (cest le registre), les saveurs de torréfaction succède à lalcool qui réchauffe le tout. La finale dune bonne amertume laisse présager un grand potentiel de vieillissement. À ta santé Tomme !!!

0.75l bottle @ Baran shared with ClubGonzo. Pours a near black body with a small tanned everlasting head leaving big lacing down the glass. Aroma is not overwhelmingly strong, but there are some nice hints of licorice, chocolate, cardboard (only in a good way) and faint malts. The body is chewy, but perhaps a bit lighter than I would have thought, and the carbonation is mostly soft. The taste is dominated by strong licorice. Also there are notes of warming alcohol, strong leather, lasting sweet chocolate, milky vanilla and roasted coffee. Really nice and scary light drinkable for a 10% abv. Ends in a slightly woody and ashy roasted lasting aftertaste just stating that this brew is  packed with flavors. Nice one!

Bottle shared with Palme @ Baran, Bergen. Deep brown, near-black body with a small white head. Aroma is licorice, chocolate, hints of coffee, nuts and tar. Nice. Taste is licorice, dark chocolate, hints of soy and wood. Some tones of caramel and nuts. Quite compex. Palate is relatively light for the well-hidden ABV and flavor profile, making it dangerously easy to drink although I think it somehow would have been better with a bit more muscle toning. Still, this ranks among my favorites from Port Brewing. Its "big brother", Older Viscosity, is even nicer but this is really a great beer.

Le liquide dévoile une robe noire surmontée dune tête mousseuse plus que convenable.  Une dentelle éparpillée saccroche au verre.  Au nez, les grains rôtis senrichissent de caramel et de notes vanillées.  Une fois bien tempérée, le liquide libère des houblons qui se choquent à un alcool parfumé en fleurs et en fruits.  Les saveurs sont succulentes, dune intensité contrôlée, fastueuses sans être exagérées : le caramel se mute en mélasse fruitée, les grains rôtis effleurés par la fumée de la torréfaction sont caressés par la force tranquille du fût de chêne et les houblons qui réussissent à percer cette ode maltée partagent un espace fin avec des flaveurs de réglisse et dalcool.  En bouche, le liquide est bien charnu, il donne une impression de densité, sa texture est bien visqueuse, moelleuse, expansive.  Leffervescence vivante du début se fatigue rapidement et cette modération apporte une sensationnelle profondeur au liquide.  La finale est complète et complexe : des notes amères de houblons et de torréfaction dans lesquelles apparaissent des notes sucrées embrasées par un alcool presque chaud et monumentalement bon.  En résumé, une illumination monstrueuse directement sortie de lempire des ténèbres.

Bottle.  Wow this is good, very different.  Pours an opaque black with a fairly small brown head.  Aroma is heavy on the mocha and toffee, a touch of licorice in there also.  Starts out with a deep, sweet toffee flavor. rounds out with a nice bitter burst of high alpha hops, and finishes out with a bitter roasted oak flavor, very long finish.  Thick and sticky on the palate, slight carbonation.  Very easy to drink despite the alcohol and all the big flavor.  Very nice, get it.

Pours a very dark black/brown with a tan and very sticky head. Smells of chocolate and toffee and caramel with malts and slight tinge of alcohol. Like the name suggests this is a very thick beer. It has great complex malt characters that let the high amounts of alcohol shine through as the beer warms up. Great sipping/after-dinner beer with a nice and warming feel to it.

The beer pours very black, with a medium tan head rising about 2 fingers but is gone pretty quickly leaving a soap head. The lacing is very good. 

The aroma is medium mostly malts, sweet chocolate, with a little leather.

The taste is nice and comples, it stats out a little sweet then gets very bitter with coffee, lots of hops and touch of leather at the end.

The feel is great, and very drinkable.

First I smell alcohol and a bit of bubblegum. There is a bit of chocolate roasty malt too. It looks like a stout, very dark. Lots of brown head that hangs around for a while. Medium bitterness with a touch of sour, but mainly sweet. Very oily with a soft feel. I would like to share this one with friends. You must try it. I would purchase this again.

Bomber into snifter. Black with a thin beige head.  Malty aroma with chocolate and bourbon barrel.  Taste is very malty, slight oak, vanilla and bourbon.  Just enough hops to keep it in check.  Very good beer.  Like a mix between an imperial stout and a barleywine.

Bottle at Maxs tasting.  The aroma is sweet cream, chocolate, coffee, very nice.   The appearance is deep brown/black, tan head.  The flavor is chocolate, brown sugar, vanilla.  Thick in body.  The finish is alcohol warming, piney hops.  Excellent.

Bottle. Very dark brown  almost black, short and fully diminishing light brown head. Moderate to heavy malty and caramel sweet aroma, coffee and some licorice. Moderate to heavy, malty and sweet flavor, lots of coffee and some licorice, roasted malt and faint hoppyness. Finish is average, malty and sweet, licorice and coffee. Sweet strong ale with coffee and licorice  not for me.

08 bottle at Maxs tasting. Pours near black with a beige head. Roasty aroma, with some fruity sweetness, chocolate, and toast. The flavor has roasted malts, dark fruit, oak, vanilla, toast, and an almost bourbon-like hint. Solid.
pours a dark brown with a nice tan head. dark fruit and oak aroma. malty. taste is chocolate, roasty, malts. dark fruit. overall a pretty decent brew.

Bottle @ Hotelroom, Denver. Black with a huge tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, caramel, vanilla. Taste is oak, coffee, chocolate, port, bit of bitter hops ala grapefruit, some alcohol. Medium body, quete high carbonation ( at least for a oak aged beer ). Very nice beer, huge flavors and really enjoyable. 120311

650ml bomber. 2010 vintage.

It pours a dense, dark brown with *gasp* a foamy tan head that sticks for a good while, but doesnt leave too much lacing.

The smell is very oaky. There is a good bit of vanilla. There is a dark, fruity, almost grapey flavor under that along with some chocolate and roastiness.

The flavor has a big sweet alcoholic bite, but it mellows. There is some oxidized fruit, caramel, coffee, chocolate, and some oak in the flavor. A good rich flavor, but perhaps a bit blunt in its delivery.

Despite the name I found this to be pretty watery.

Despite the alcohol presence, this one drinks really easy thanks to the thinner body and smooth carbonation.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-01-2010 05:39:00
Bottle on 10/22/2010. Clear dark black body with a small creamy tan head. Sweet chocolate and molasses aroma. Dark chocolate and molasses flavor. Medium full body with moderately low carbonation.

Bomber. Pours a deep dark brown color with a half-inch of light brown head. The aroma is mostly roasted malt, toffee and bittersweet chocolate. The taste begins with a blend of dark chocolate mocha, molasses and caramel malt flavors followed by butterscotch, candied dates and rum. The mouthfeel is silky and creamy with soft carbonation and a roasty, boozy finish. Very unique overall flavor that goes back and forth between an Imperial Stout and a Barley Wine.

Poured from a 22.  Very dark and thick with minimal head.  Nose was more stout like with oak, coffee, and malt.  Taste was also more stout with similar flavors.  Nice finish and well worth more in the future.

Strong aroma of coffee and malt.  Dark and strong with a sweet, full  malt and coffee flavor.  Not tangy or dodgey or funny in any way - this is a straightforward malt bomb.  Another very fine brew from Port.
Thick, tan head with staying power.  Aroma of chocolate, and caramel, and amazing.  Super thick palate, with so much complexity itll take the whole 22 to find even half of them. Really great.

18-FEB-2011, bottle @home, from "Fish & Beer".
I loved the older about a year ago, so how is this old one?
Dark dark brown with huge head that dies right away leaving a very small beige rim.
Roasted grinded coffee nose and taste. Very much like a porter with roasted notes. Ends hoppy bitter but that in no way changes the porter impression.
Quite high carbonation, a surprice since older was still.
Cannot help being a little disappointed. Dont get me wrong, its a fantastic porter but not what I hoped for. (6-3-8-4-15=36).
As it warms, more alcoholic, more complex, more barrel-aged:-)
Bourbon notes show up now. Really almost hurts the mouth now. Alcohol is very present.
Now way more than a porter, and I must up the rating. Really smooth and well-made. Glad to have had this one.

22oz bottle, unknown date, probably 6+ months old.  Pours dark brown to black with a 3 finger brown head that leaves tons of clumpy lacing and holds a good cap.  Aroma is dark fruits, cocoa, coffee, toast, caramel, molasses, very good strength.  Flavor is rich chocolate and cocoa, coffee, dark fruits, anise, molasses, toffee, caramel, dark bread, minimal alcohol.  Moderate sweetness low bitterness.  Mouthfeel is medium to full, creamy, medium to sometimes prickly carbonation.  Another fantastic brew from Port.  Tough to classify, but is most reminiscent of an Imperial Stout.

Bottle shared with 4 friends.
An aptly named beer!  Dark and thick.  Deecent head.  Tasty :-)

Pours inky black with a medium darker tan head.  Leaves thick, sticky lacing all the way down.  Aroma is not as strong as the look (and flavor) suggests.  I smell mild chocolate notes, some dark roasted spiced malt, an a strange acidic funk that I normally associate with sour browns.  Taste is a dark chocolate, coffee, spice, malt and tangy fruit bomb.  It has a thick clingy mouthfeel like a stout, but a nice, lively fizz like a belgian.  Finish is ripe, sugary fruit, chocolate and a good oaky, boozy kick.  This is a very excellent beer.  One of my favorites.

22oz bottle.  deep brown with ruby hues under a very large, foamy, tan head.  cocoa, dark fruit, wet tobacco leaves.  flavor is woody and oaky with milk chocolate.  bitter hops occasionally.  creamy body almost lactose-like.  warming and medium bodied.  bitter finish.  not really anything like older from what i remember.

Mmmm...On tap, poured almost black, if it wasnt for the lighting i would have said straight black.  Had a very thin head that dissipated within a minute and had a lot of lacing that clung to the glass the whole way down.  The pour was ice cold so i had to sit there while the flavors opened up.  Toasted malts, chocolate and a little vanilla on the nose.  Taste is fantastic, Malty, good amount of bitter chocolate, little vanilla, and a not to sweet but sweet finish.  Nice carbonation and silky mouth feel.  Great overall beer highly recommend it.

Black pour with a nice sized off white head, tight.  Nice lace.  Aroma was rich roasted malts, chocolate, maybe some light wood and vanilla.  Flavors were right on point, lots of roast, light woody notes throughout, dark bitter cocoa with a hot boozy finish.  Finished with a big bittersweet, more bitter cocoa like finish.  Mouthfeel was medium to full, a bit lacking in this sense.  No carbonation issues, nice.  Overall this is pretty decent stuff but its nothing that I pine over after the bottle ends...
Black with a small light brown head. Sweet chocolate and coffee with light bourbo notes and some dark fruits. Medium to heavy body.

Poured black with a large foamy stable tan head.  Aroma of ... olives?  Also chocolate malts and coffee.  Taste has lots of chocolate and coffee.  Some brown sugar and molasses.  Aftertaste has some alcohol in it.  Overall very nice and unique.

Pours a very dark blackish color which was unexpected.  Has a dark brown head that was rather foamy and large.  Smells of sugar, roasted malts and some nuts.  Taste is a bit sweet.  Taste has some caramel mixed in with some almonds.

Pour nice and oily...and Id agree this isnt "your Dads Wimpy 30 weight"....its more like a 10W-30......which to me means its actually thinner....but will still get you going on a cold day (and let me tell you, its cold out right now).  Very little head, but still looks decent in the glass.  Has a sort of tartness to it...and a malty sweet-ish spice to it...almost like a bit of fennel or something.  Very drinkable...and enjoyable....but perhaps a bit underwhelming for what Ive come to expect of a strong ale.

After poring, I thought for sure this was an imperial stout because of how black it is. It tastes are very unique. Not many stouts have this flavor, some would but those are the very highly rated like Bells Expedition. It misses one thing most imperial stouts have which is a dark bitter chocolate flavor, it has more of a dark fruit flavor. I assume that is the reason this beer was labeled as an American Strong ale instead of a stout.  I cant get this beer in my home town but was able to find it in Seattle area. Well worth the wait, got late September 2010.  Drinking it now. It aged very well though I dont know how it would have tasted before ageing, but I found it very smooth. It was also difficult to taste any alcohol notes. This has very sweet flavor from the beginning, middle and end. A beer worth paying and finding if you can.

Review from notes, sampled 1/30/2008
Poured from a growler received in a GIF from IntriqKen Thanks for the opportunity.

Pours a solid black that no light gets through. Starts with a thin tan head that goes away quickly. Aroma is really nice chocolates, coffee, some dried fruit, a little caramel. Taste follows the smell, but adds some alcohol bite in the end. Mouthfeel is thick as promised. Excellent brew, very complex, thick, tasty. Send more.

Bottle I think bought in Boston of all places. Man, this was really nice. Super, dark pour with a thick brown head and crazy lacing. Both the aroma and the flavor were heavy with chocolate, roasted/burnt malt and a hint of booze. I think this bottle was about 2.5 years old which might have mellowed some of the 10ABV. Tasty.

On tap at Trappeze in Athens, GA. This sat inky black in a Belgian-style glass beneath a cap of khaki foam. True to its name, it is inky and viscous. The texture is smooth and the body not too heavy, and the flavors are just what you expect from a big stout. Unfortunately, it is a bit too heavy on the fennel and licorice for my taste, but its still a nice sipper.

Very dark brown /black with virtually no head. Smells of very sweet chocolates, some coffee, roasted malts and vanilla. Taste is roasted malts and bitter earthy hops up front with medium plus alcohol. The chocolate and coffee notes taking a back seat. Full body, somewhat syrupy, lite carbonation, decent bitter bite and dry finish with big alcohol warmth. The Hops and alcohol are a big part of this brew with the roasty malts and other flavors helping out in the background. A bold brew that should be sipped and savored.

660 ml bottle shared with dad. Pitch black lasting mocha head. A: Chocolaty, roasted malt, some caramel. F: Full body nice residual sugar. Finish is sweet and medium long . P: excellent mouthfeel, it has a velvety texture. O: Pleasant from the first sip to the last.

Bottle. Pours dark ruby with a tan head. Aroma is chocolate milkshake and espresso. Flavor is light, like drinking chocolate milk with a bit of coffee. Just fantastic beer, why this is not a 4+ average is beyond me.

Poured into a snifter.

3.5 A: Black, stout-like color. Aggressive pour yielded 2 fingers of frothy tan head. Unfortunately the head fell very quickly, but did leave a decent amount of lacing.

4.5 S: Very nice aroma. Theres a lot of dark malt aromas, but nothing burnt. Seems like there are several different crystal malts going on here and lend a complex sweetness. This sweetness is backed up with a hit of espresso. In the background, there are dark fruits with emphasis on black cherries. Touch of alcohol in the nose. This would be an easy five if the aroma were more pronounced.

4.5 T: I can see where the confusion comes from when classifying this beer. I taste Olde Ale, Stout, and Barleywine. Dark fruits including black cherries and raisins. Sweet caramel malts and plenty of espresso in the taste as well. Healthy bitterness from hops and dark malts. Oak and alcohol show up to the party and both complement. I love oaked brews, so this was a great addition.

4.0 M: Heavy body, but not too heavy, though it is syrupy and chewy. Low carbonation, but it works pretty well. Some alcohol warming on finish.

4.5 D: Very good brew. Im incredibly happy that I chose this one to bring back from Arizona. For how intense it is, it goes down extremely well.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-03-2009 02:08:32

650ml bomber from Wholefoods Market in Santa Monica. Pours black with tan head and some foamy lace. Aroma is roasted malts, coffee, dark chocolate and figs. Flavor is malty bitter sweet chocolate, coffee, bready yeast and toasted malts. Thick bodied, with noticeable, though not overpowering alcohol. Nice lingering aftertaste.

22oz bottle in a snifter.  Pours black with a thick, lacy, tan head.  Aroma of roasted malts, some coffee, some smokiness, and some hops that balance it out.  Flavor really strong of the roasted malts, some smokiness, and a coffee flavor that is in the background but strong on the finish with some oak.  Very long finish.  An incredible beer.

(bottle - 22 oz) Dark black pour with very little head or carbonation. Coffee, cocoa, toffee and wood are very prevalent in the aroma with some hints of dark fruits underneath. Roasted flavor at the start with a very mild chocolate and coffee combination in the middle. Theres a little dark fruity hint coming up near the end before it moves to a robust and roasty finish. Full-bodied and really flavorful.

Viscous black, no head, looks like motor oil... Some coffee, creamy, a little vanilla, roasty aroma... Some dark fruits, a little oaky in the flavor... Creamy, smooth, silky mouthfeel, medium full bodied... Not nearly as bold or pungent as i expected..
UPDATED: SEP 5, 2011 65cl, American brew, from De Hopduvel Gent, complex brew, heavy, yet balanced, hazy, small head, very good brew, yet expensive!

Bottle; Pour is a Dark Brown/Black with a very modest tan head that rings the glass after dissipating quickly. Not really what I was expecting out of an "American Strong". Anyway - Cocoa, Toffee, and Light Citrus on the nose.  The Heavy malts blend well with the Hop presence, though it might dominate just a wee bit. There is a citrus/grapefruit hop element, but the chocolate, caramel, toffee malty feel is what is more obvious. This brew really works -

coffee and dry chocolate aroma with a faint alcohol and sweet grape like appearance is black, with no transparency at all thick creamy tan head first taste is coffee and finishes very smooth and you can faintly taste the oak barrel with some definite chocolate in there the mouthfeel is an awesome creaminess pretty well carbonated for how thick it is as well

UPDATED: OCT 20, 2011 Bottled @ home.  Deep pitch black appearance with a big dark brown head.  Deep roasted malty aroma with a fairly significant alcohol smell.  Dark roasted flavor initially with a creamy and tingly mouthfeel.  Very strong flavor from the dark malts and alcohol.  Pretty hoppy and bitter finish and aftertaste.  A lot of flavor going on in this beer.
Pours a dark brown-black with a tan foamy head. Aroma is caramel and light coffee. Malty, some wood, vanilla middle.Thick and creamy with dry finish. Served a little too cold.

Pours black. Nose is roasted malts, coffee, molases, raisins, plums, breads, and toasted malts. Taste is largely roasted, burnt, and sweetly malty. Heavy bodied, and smooh on the palate. Good. a little on the carbed side and a little on the burnt roasted side.

Id put this beer more in the stout category.  Pours black with little head.  Nice aroma of malt, molasses and hops.  Full bodied with a really nice smooth palate.  Well balanced with sweetness, malt and hops.  Excellent beer.

Pours black with dark brown head leaving lace. Malty, tar, alcoho, oak barrel a bit thin aroma. Fruity and smokey mouthfeel. Fruity, acidy smokey, tary yet not fullbodied flavor. Finishes shortlived tart bitter.

Bottle from Cavie.  Pours like the oil from my 1991 Suburban, which I guess is the point.  Aroma is alcohol, chocolate, and then a little alcohol.  Taste is even more alcohol, but then a great roasted flavor and bakers cocoa flavor.  Alcohol in the finish again.

Bottle courtesy bu11zeye. Pours a dark brown color with a light brown bubbly head. Aroma is woody and caramel malts. Strong sugar. Flavor is dark Malts and wood. Vanilla bourbon notes. Very flavorful with some heavy flavors near the finish. Nice.

Pours a pitch black colour with a medium tan head. Aroma is of toasted malts, chocolate, oak, and booze. Taste is slightly sweet and malty with a dry bitterness to it. Full bodied, thick on the palate, soft carbonation. Overall a very good beer, definitely worth getting at least once.

Picked up a bottle at Binnys in Chicago.  This is damn good! Aroma is full of burnt malts, tons of fruit, and alcohol.  The flavor is excellent, with lots of rich malts, chocolate, fruit, coca-cola, and light bourbon. My only complain is that it is basically flat with almost no carbonation.  An aggressive pour yielded a small barely noticeable tan head which faded quickly.  Even with it being flat, its still full bodied with a smooth thick palate.  Great beer.
Sorprendente ale añejada en barrica de madera que sorprende por su gran intensidad en boca y un retrogusto en el que vuelve madera y fruta madura con pinceladas de malta tostada.

Bouteille de 22 oz. Arômes de chocolat noir et de céréales, légère touche boisée. Robe noire et opaque, peu de mousse et effervescence assez faible. En bouche, on retrouve beaucoup de chocolat au lait et de caramel brûlé. Lapport du chêne demeure discret et bien équilibré. Malgré ses belles notes maltées, la bière nest pas particulièrement corpulente et sucrée. Finale présentant une amertume relativement forte. Près dune Imperial Stout, sans présenter de fortes notes torréfiées. Une bonne bière dessert.

Hell yeah! Thanks for some of this ScottyP. Pours solid black with a creamy tan head. Aroma of dark chocolate and some smoke. taste has lots of bitterness, hop, cocoa, ashy malt. Alcohol is somewhat noticeable. Damn good stuff.
Had in 11/10 - going from memory - pitch black pour = motor oil;  great thick palate with a roasted flavor; will have and re rate again

Pours like a heavily carbonated stout, with a big, tan head that never entirely dissipates.  Nose is bit of coffee, yeast and alcohol.  Flavor is incredibly smooth for such a strong beer.  Theres no indication of the 10% ABV, so the oak aging clearly did its job.  I would say the flavor is predominantly coffee and vanilla, but its just such an enjoyable, drinkable beer that isnt too overpowering or heavy.  I really enjoyed this and would say it is by far the best offering under the Port label that Ive had to date.

5th Epic and Rare gathering.  Surprised this isnt an IS.  Black.  Aroma and flavor match, nicely layered and balanced notes of coffee and chocolate, quite smooth considering the ABV.  I would describe it as a very well executed standard IS.  Really enjoyed it more than this description can adequately depict.

Surprised to see this categorized as an American Strong Ale, as characteristic-wise, it gives the impression of meandering somewhere between an imperial oatmeal stout and an imperial stout. However, the most accurate way to characterize this brew, is to simply call it darn good--in fact, outstanding. The pour fills the glass with a gorgeous dark chocolate body primly topped by a wafter thin chocolate cream head. Apportioned with a tantalizing chocolate and roast coffee nose--blissful. Bitter dark chocolate body upon what a discernably high caliber fresh-milled grain backbone. Just the brew for the cooler seasons.
This is a chewy monster of an ale. It really seems like a stout to me. Pours dark, tastes dark, drinks warm. Delicious way to spend a cold desert evening.

Bottle. Thick, black pour with a foamy tan head that lasts a little while. Roasty aroma is quite roasty with notes of dark chocolate, liquorice and smoke. Flavour is very similar to the aroma: roasty and smokey with coffee, vanilla and rum mingling with the chocolate and liquorice. Thick, creamy mouthfeel with fine, moderate carbonation and a lingering roasty, bitter finish. Big, complex and easy to drink, this is a great dark ale.

Bottle. Pours a very dark brown with super creamy tan coloured head. Good lacing. Aromas of roasted grain. dark chocolate, espresso and some dark fruits. Good stuff. Flavours are brilliant. Lots of roasted malt bitterness and a touch of smoke. Slightly sour bitter finish. Medium creamy mouthfeel. Great beer.

On draft.  Pours pitch black with a little offwhite head.  Nose is earth, coffee, and vanilla.  Notes of same, malty sweet vanilla and caramel with oak and bourbon.  Finishes with coffee and malt.  Very enjoyable.
Thick and luxurious beer with flavours of chocolate, tobacco, dark fruits, bourbon oak and alcohol. Really rich and warming, very impressive hybrid stout.

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2010 22 oz. bottle, pours black with a small tan head. Aroma of dark chocolate, dark fruits, and caramel. Extremely rich and complex palate, with dark dark chocolate, dark fruits, a little bourbon, vanilla and oak. Absolutely wonderful treat.
Pit black with a lovely lasting thick brown head. Chocolate, ashes, vanilla, some oak, a burnt note in the end. Is a luscious, thick, flavourful roasted experience.

SÖF 25 year feast at Haket 2010-11-13 Göteborg - big bottle
AP: pitch black, wee beige head to start with
AR: vanilla beans, dark chocloate, whiskey, sprity, fudgy
F: bitter chocolate, wee toffee, some coffey, loads of roasted malt

Black, small head.  Roasted malt, burnt sugar, wood, and dust aroma.  The aroma isnt much to me, but the flavor makes up a bit for it as well as the drinkability.  Tastes and feels like some Imp stouts.

Definitely a Strong Ale, and it is from America. Glad we cleared that up. Anyways, when it says Strong, it means it. I struggled to get this one down. And to make matters worse, I had a Young Double Chocolate Stout waiting for me afterward which I could barely taste thanks to this monstrosity.

Appearance: Pours a jet black with a tan creamy layer of film atop.

Aroma: Coffee, dark chocolate, vanilla and malted milk.

Taste: Roast, dark chocolate, vanilla, spicy hops. Finishes with burnt roast.

Mouthfeel: Full bodied with lively carbonation.

Overall: A very enjoyable, complex dark beer.

FInally getting around to rating this one. Ok. Nose is full of dark malts, sweeter chocoalte notes, dark fruits, light roast, earthy aromas as well. Pours dark, black with a tan lasting head and nice lace. Sweet flavors of dark fruit, chocolate, roasted malts, caramels, some residual sugars, light dryness, earthy hops hints of bitterness. Lingering balanced sweetness. Alcohol shows through but all in all this is a wonderful beer.

650 ml bottle.
Pours a dark brown colour with a small patchy and lacy head. Aroma of oak, fruits and syrup. Flavour of toasted malts, sweet fruits, some hops and sticky syrup. Full bodied and round carbonation. Nice brew and the oak aging does feel here.

650ml bottle from Bierkompass

Tasty, sweet ale. Well balanced, neither alcohol nor oak dominate the taste. Almost like barley wine, but not quite as complex.

650mL bottle.  Pours opaque black with a persistent tan ring.  Sweet, roasty, woody aroma with vanilla and some alcohol.  Flavour is more of the same, a little dark fruit, medium sweetness, chocolate, a little roast bitterness and the alcohol adds a bite.  Medium bodied, soft carbonation, fairly smooth with a lasting finish.

1 pt. 6 fl. oz. bottle, courtesy of Cardinal Pub & Bar, Stavanger. ABV is 10.0%. Black colour (dark ruby when held to the light), huge tan head. Lovely aroma of moderately roasted malts, mild coffee, chocolate, oak and leather. Full and rich flavour, malty predominance with much the same elements as the aroma, moderate but sufficient hops in the finish. Well balanced, immensely pleasant to drink. Warming mouthfeel, but the alcohol is otherwise well hidden in the flavour.

22 oz. bottle shared by Dan- thanks again!  Pours a cloudy dark brown color with a small tan ring for a head.  Aroma is huge on chocolate, along with cream, caramel, coffee, wood, and roasted malts.  The flavor follows suit pretty closely, with touch of molasses and smoke.  Medium-full bodied, with low carbonation and a roasty mouthfeel.  I have a bottle of this and Older Viscosity I want to try side by side, and this is drinking pretty well now so I might have to do that soon.

UPDATED: OCT 27, 2010 Subtle almost fruity aroma. Dark black pour with a slight brown head. Thick and heavily bodied just like the bottle says. Has a slightly caramel and bitter flavor.  This beer mixes my love of Strong Ales and Porters. Its fantastic. The 22oz is a perfect beer to share. Received in a trade from Matt from San Fran.
Only had this beer twice(bottle). Not as thick as it sounds. Very smooth on the palate w/ multiple notes coming and going. Very flavorful, rich ale

Just from pouring and smelling this ale, its easily imaginable how they arrived at its name.  Molasses, oak, malt, roasty aromas and flavors.  Healthy but not overwhelming bitterness in the finish.  As it warms, I am getting red wine notes.  I love this brewery more and more with every beer I try.

Serving: 22 oz. bottle from Julios Liquors. 
Aroma: The nose is big with a bit of oak, dark fruit, fig, prune, chocolate malt, and patent malt. 
Appearance: It pours almost pitch black with slight ruby highlights and a substantial, creamy, light tan head. 
Taste: The flavor is malt forward with a good bit of roasty bitterness.  The wood and a slight booziness come through as well.  Dark fruit, prune, plum, and a pinch of chocolate round things out. 
Palate: Medium to rich body with high carbonation and a slightly boozy, roasty finish. 
Overall: A big, deep, dark, rich brew that has layers of depth and flavor.  Highly recommended!
Bomber poured dark knight black with a nice tan head.  Great nose loaded with molasses, roasted malt, and toffee.  The flavor is slightly bitter with roasted malt, bitter chocolate, and licorice.

22 oz bottle.  Pours an almost pitch black with a small chocolaty tan head leaving a decent amount of lacing on the glass.  Aroma is chocolate, molasses, licorice, and strong of alcohol.  Initial taste is anise, then a bit of chocolate comes through.  Finish is warm with alcohol.  Light-medium body.  Low-medium carbonation.

bouteille de markwise.
couleur sombre noire, col est foncé.
ressort des notes finement houblonées, le seul point négatif de cette bière est le niveau dalcool que je trouve trop dominant, la mise en fût de cette bière reste moyen et couvert principalement par le %.
Niveau de malt est élevé, grille et chocolat, poudre de cacao, dommage que le palais garde cet aspect dalcool intense qui gâche un peu lexpérience.

UPDATED: SEP 23, 2010 Bottle, home, poured into a goblet glass. Excellent bold and strong lacing, which peters out to a gorgeous creamy white lacing. Opaque black colour, Aroma of mead, wood, roasted malts, burnt toast, coffee beans, taste chocolate coffee beans, vanilla, oil, some cream, mead, oak bourbon at the end, some earthy flavour and an excellent bitterness. This beer is mesmerising. Very complex on the tongue and dry roasted malt finish which is really LOOOOOOOOOOOONG.

Stunning. What an ace way to anticipate Borefts!

Excellent beer.  Pours very dark.  Has little head.  Subdued malty sweetness and nice hops.  Im learning to like stouts, and to me this is very similar to a stout in character, but more complex and very, very smooth for the style.

Bottle, thanks to Rachel for bringing something this amazingly highly-rated back for me. Pours thick and viscous black medium non-persistent head, with very good to excellent lacing. Nose is molasses, oak, smoke, tar, nice roast malt character, some coconut and vanilla here too. Flavours are very roasty and bitter, some real smokiness here, toasted marshmallows and vanilla too. Very soft and rich, but with nice bitterness for balance. Not the equal of the Older Viscosity.

Bottle.  Aroma has notes of roasted malts, licorice, molasses, caramel, chocolate, vanilla and oak.  Dark brown hue that sits black in the glass with an average off-white head that mostly diminished and left good lace.  Flavor is heavy sweet with a medium/heavy bitterness.  Palate is very full bodied with average carbonation and a long cloying finish.  Overall a thick, rich and delicious brew.  Lots of roasted malts, chocolates and woody tones.

22oz bottle from Bottleworks in Seattle. Pours a near pitch black...or at least a very dark brown. Little to no lasting head, just a thin tan ring. Aroma is super malty with a good hop hit. Taste is thick and overwhelmingly toffee, caramel malt. Sharp bite in the finish. Overall this beer is delicious and complex. I keep benchmarking it against Arrogant Bastard but, dare I say it, its better.
Bottle with the bros in Philly from foodery II.   Nose was nothing special.  Reminded menor of self righteous ale but leaning more on the stout side.
Great brew had with nick. Pour is thick black. Medium head. Aroma is dark malts with some hits of oaky hops. Flavor is full or malts, earth tones, and mild molasis. Well balanced.

A: snifter. pours an abyss-like obsidian color, with a rich tan head. good head retention and great lacing.

S: roasted malts, coconut, cherries, white pepper, and a serious bourbon aroma.

T: some major bourbon flavors, macaroons, cherries with tons of oak. some coffee, chocolate, and toffee, as well.

M: this brew has a big beefy body to it. outstanding palate, and a mild carbonation level.

D: wow, this beer is phenomenal. One of the best I have had yet. Well worth getting if you have the means.

Bottle, shared with Parksy and Josephson. Pours a deep, murky near-black with mahogany highlights. Aroma is dark caramel, dark roast coffee, chocolate, with piney, leafy hop accents. Flavours are hard roast, chocolate, soft woody and vanilla accents. Big and chewy, with a medium pine and pith bitterness in the finish. Tremendously satisfying.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: (cask GBBF ). 2009 VINTAGE sample .....2010 experince.   A little roller-coaster  through a gigantic stench of Burbon barrells flying up into my brain....ecstasy in seas of sohisticated malts ... living the good life aged in complex   houses.   Classy .
UPDATED: DEC 20, 2010 Consumed with Travlr on 23 Aug 10. Dark pour with good head - sticks to the side of the glass. Mild on the smell - but smokey flavor and good sharpness tongue. A "must drink."
Bomber shared with steptin.  Black.  Dark brown head.  Aroma of cocoa powder and dark milk chocolate.  Taste is smooth, rich Hershey bar with a bit of Lindts.  Dry and slightly bitter finish.

Tried a bomber bottle that I picked up at Best Damn Beer Shop in San Diego, CA.  They dont call it Old Viscosity for nothin; it pours a very dark brown (almost black) with a creamy, light tan head, and it looks pretty thick, easily coating the side of a glass.  Aromas of dark chocolate and alcohol...  Tastes wonderfully dark--full of roasty malt, nutty chocolate and brown sugar flavors and a very long, pronounced coffee-like finish.  That lovely, smoky, mellow bitterness makes this a great beer to spend some time sipping on; its quite rich and complex, and would be nice to relax with.  Cheers!
Im sure everyone has said plenty about this beer! On draft side by side with the older is the only way to do it.

awesome brew that left me wanting more.  Pours dark muddy brown (almost black) with beige head.  Chocolate, toffee, caramel with hints of vanilla and wood predominate t5eh nose and taste.  Very smooth an easy to drinkfor a beer with this much flavour.  One of my favourites for sure.

Bottle poured on 7/27/10 into a tulip glass produced a muddy black body with a frothy dark brown head.  Aroma of chocolate and brown sugar.  Flavors were caramel, roasted malts, toffee, vanilla, and wood.  A delicious, full-bodied, and creamy treat for the palate.
If cough syrup was carbonated and came in molasses flavor, it would taste just like this. [LBD20]
black with tan head.  molasses and roast malt aroma with a hint of alcohol.   the flavor is bitter and spicy with smoke and chocolate.  tasty.

Bottle-deep brown burnt black hue with a fizzy brown head.  nose is of molassis, oak, char, plums, dust and some lite chocolate.  deep coca and more char come through as it warms.  big chocolate flavors with anise, char and figs.  really cool brew but really not my style (but i rate them accordingly).  long oaky/woody finish mixed with dark chocolate.  I was kind of expecting something a bit different (maybe more hops) but for what this was, it was very good!

A damn fine beer, I would drink it until my liver gave way. Nothing offensive at all, just beer bliss. Would get again fo sho.
Not hot with booze on the pallat, but it wars your gullet and will make you salivate. roasty and deep and complex. this one is overlooked far too often.

(22oz. bottle).  Pours black with red hues and thick, tan head.  Aroma is dark-roasted coffee, berries, alcohol.  Taste is sweet with burnt notes and some hops.  The hops seem to be overwhelmed by the burnt character of the beer.  Full bodied and almost syrupy, the finish is somewhat bitter.  This is obviously a sipping beer and one that should be savored.

This pours out a dark red-brown, but not nearly as black or as viscous as the label would have you believe.  A thin head lows into a sticky lacing.  On the nose there is a sweet wooded vanilla reminiscent of an unpeated whiskey.  Then comes ash, tobacco and leather with subtle notes of chocolate and coffee, and a hint of balsamic vinegar.  In the mouth it gives over to the barrel aging.  Foremost is vanilla and smoke, but there is a vinousness here; lots of sharp tannins and nutty bittering, meaning that this drinks like an imperial porter and not a stout.  The smokiness is strong.  It rises to the back of the nose where it remains, giving off the lingering aroma of an ashtray - but in a good sort of a way.  Its like walking into an English country pub on a Sunday afternoon.  Mouth feel is creamy, but could be thicker.  The finish returns to ash and oak.  In the end it is a complex, challenging beer, and enjoyably so.  However, it does little to live up to the label, which seems to have been written by an overly stimulated advertising intern.
pronounced coffee, vanilla, berries, highly astringent, burnt toffee - a challenging beer to say the least; still, Ill gladly take another

Tunt skum har den, men oj vad den doftar gott! Härliga aromer av choklad, en aning bröd, rostade kaffebönor och vanilj.
Ölen har en härlig halvtjock och oljig känsla. Smaken är lika god och komplex som doften och jag tycker även jag får lite gräddiga associationer. Den har också härliga toner av kola, russin och torkade plommon

Bottle. 25.4 oz. Courtesy of and split with James. Pours a deep, opaque motor-oil brown with a modest amber head that recedes quickly and leaves sludgy tan lacing. Aroma of cocoa nibs, fresh coffee beans, roast, sweet malts, vanilla, toffee, and hints of smoke. Full, thick body with a viciously heavy, fudge-like palate. Creamy, bold finish with a bit of spice and burn. Another gem from Tomme Arthur and Port Brewing / Lost Abbey. Incredible American strong.

UPDATED: AUG 16, 2010 Bottle split with Pat.  Pours a pitch jet black body with small brown lacing..nice lacing - lots of sediment. Aroma is spicy, deliciously complex. Notes of chocolate, molasses, bitterness, chewy but silky palate.

Rating 800. Huge Beer. This is an imperial porter, but not like any I have had before. Huge mouthfeel, really full. on the nose is lots of chocolate, dark fruit and alcohol. In the mouth it is full and sticky, with a myriad of flavours dancing on the tongue. Just a really great sipping beer and one of those beers that makes you go wow"!
This is indeed a hefty brew.  Aroma is somewhat hoppier than the taste, which is thick, syrupy, and sweep.  A good beer to experience, but one that requires some time to savor.

Bottle:  Poured a dark brown almost black color with a nice head.  The aroma was roasted malts, dark chocolate, and a hint of coffee.  The flavor was sweet, bitter, smooth, coffee, dark chocolate and malt.  Overall, one of the better beers on the market that is easier to get.

Bomber, bottled on Halloween Day, 2009. I like to think it was bottled at midnight on Halloween Night. One of my favorite stouts, so Ill admit my bias up front. Pours black, opaque. All I can see through the glass is my own reflection. So, yeah, it looks good. Tan head, which lingers. Looks just like a stout should. An Imperial stout, that is. I smell: Chocolate (sweet, not dark), vanilla, roasted malts. I taste: Chocolate, tobacco,  some coffee-like bitterness, and a lingering burn that is a combination of hops and alcohol. Either way, I wont be able to taste a thing after this beer. Full bodied, in the way that a good woman is full bodied. Curvaceous, smooth, firm, willing. This beer winks and says, "I know how good I am. What do you have to offer?" Fortunately, I know I can afford it. Ill remember Miss Visc at least until the morning. After that, all bets are off. One hell of a one night stand. Cheers.

A very dark brown (almost black) beer with a smallish tan head. Aroma is all roast malt - chocolate, burnt toast, and alcohol. Flavor has the same burnt notes, coffee too, and also some dark fruitiness like plum in the background. Decent hop bitterness, and lots of alcohol heat. Somewhat chewy mouthfeel. This seems more like an imperial stout than anything else, and there are much better examples of that style.

Bottle at 4:20 at RBESG Rome. Clear dark brown to black colour, beige head. Aroma of salt, light smoked and roasted malts, chocolate. Flavour is light smoked, bit salty, chocolate, good coffee/roasted/chocolate bitter finish. Medium to fullbodied. Really good.

UPDATED: JUN 1, 2010 Pours black with a tan head. Nose is very full. Lots of coffee bean, roasted malts, chocolate and smoked bourbon barrels. Taste is similar. Very dry. The coffee and roasted malts really shine through. Well balanced. The bourbon is a little more present than Id have liked, but it doesnt distract too much from the well balanced brew.

2007 Vintage
5/20/2010:  Port Brewing Old Viscosity Ale...  Aroma:  Semi-sweet chocolate, sweet anise/root beer, heavily caramelized malts, chocolate cake.  Appearance:  Pretty much black and opaque; minimal carbonation; frothy dark beige to tan-colored crown that is persistent and leaves nice lacing on the glass.  Flavor:  Rich and somewhat roasty with a good level of residual sweetness and just enough alcohol showing through to tickle the palate; rich caramelization with a char edge to it; semi-sweet and dark chocolate; heavy molasses taste; smooth vanilla quality; touches of coffee and earthy hops.  Palate:  Medium-full; milky texture; smooth going down; a bit sticky on the lips.  Overall:  Really damn good; everything that I needed in a beer right now; met and exceeded expectations.
 fl. oz. bottle (10$ acl. [sic] by vol.) from realale420 via trade in 2007.  Thank Brian!  Rating #812 for this beer.

22 oz. bottle from Liquid Gratitude. Pours black, with a tan head. The taste and aroma is chocolate and malt. Alcohol warms the palate, but sublty. Very smooth, very drinkable, I like this one quite a lot. Thumbs way up.
Bottled. Opaque black appearance, very small head. Very malty nose, chocolate, vinous, very complex. Complex and sweet flavor. Not as good as the Older Viscosity, but still very good.

Bottle shared by Eric, thank 
Appearance: Pours black with a tan head and some lacing 
Aroma: Roasted malts, chocolate and coffee 
Taste: Smooth mouthfeel. Roasted malts and chocolate 
Very nice beer.

Pours a dark brown, no make that black and not much of a head. What there was is tan. Smells of roasted malt and coffee. A thick beer that sticks to your tongue. An earthy and strong malt taste to it.

Bomber from Pizza Port Carlsbad.  Great... fantastic pours out thick dark brown, almost black, impenetrable with a wonderful brownish head.  The aroma is pure toasted malts, chocolates and earth.  Its silky and smooth and caresses the palate all the while pouring huge amounts of malt and hops.  The alcohol is completely hidden.  Truly a gem.

Pours a nice thick black color with an almost brown head.  Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate, and vanilla.  Flavor of coffee, roasted malts, chocolate, and hops.  Touch of alcohol on the back end.  Creamy mouth feel.  Impressive beer!

22 oz. bottle from South Bay Drugs.  Pours brown, nearly black, with a thin tan head.  The aroma is of rich chocolatey malt and floral hops.  Beautiful blend of the floral hops and smoky malts.  Think along the lines of somewhere between an Imperial Stout and a black IPA.  Thick mouthfeel.  Moderate alcohol warming.  Exceptional.

Brown, nearly black. Small head, fine bubbles. Lacing in sheets. Nose is roasty and vinous. This is sort of a hoppy barleywine crossed w/ a stout w/ a sour twist. Thick but w/ very fine carbonation. Sticky sweet, coffee-like and slightly oxidative--sherry and a faint touch of cardboard. Alcohol warms the belly. Nice strong ale w/ many facets but not a home run.

A- Body is a thick, viscous opaque dark brown (nearly black) hue. Pours with a nice 2 finger or so light tan head that eventually fades to a thick collar and leaves plenty of lacing behind in the glass.

S-Milk chocolate, bourbon sweetness, vanilla, roasted cofee, and a touch of phenols. Pretty complex and I cant pick up everything.

T- The flavor upfront is somewhat subtle and offers mostly dark chocolate and roasted coffee bean flavors. The roasted characteristics come through a bit more for the finish along with a bourbon sweetness and heat. What lingers is roasted flavors and a nice warm alcohol heat (nothing overpowering).

P-High tingly carbonation but mouthfeel is very smooth and viscous. Not at all influenced by alcohol.

O- This is a nice strong ale/hybrid. My 1st Port brew that isnt an IPA. This makes me really want to age on of these...or to find older viscosity. Very good and well done. Its hot...but not too hot.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-17-2009 03:43:04
Very good.  Tastes like a coffee porter.  I see this compared to Serpents Stout - for the price, Ill take this, but for overall quality I think the Serpents stout wins for me.

Bottle via HogTownHarry - thanks, Harry! Pour is just as the name suggests - deep and dark and oil-like, with a thick tan head. Aroma and flavour both hold notes of coffee, cocoa, dark roasted malt, charred wood, vanilla and molasses. Big mouthfeel. Finish is dry and roasty with a bit of booziness. Lovely!

22 oz bottle.  Pours black with a tan head.  Aroma has lots of chocolate, cream, and vanilla.  Flavor is very roasty with dark chocolate and coffee.  Perhaps some woody hints and anise.  Fairly bitter finish that seems to come more from roasted malts than from hops.  Good stuff.

Pours dark brown and opaque with a thin tan head.  Yeasty residue clumps a bottom of glass.  Coffee and brown sugar, smoky flavor, bitter sweet aftertaste.  Hop flavor is very subdued, so comes across closer to many imperial stouts.

From bottle at a tasting.
Aroma : Roasted malt, some chocolate and some coffee. Quite malty overall.

Taste : Roasted malt, coffee and some hops. Finish is hoppy with roasted malt. Quite dry.

Overall : Second time Ive had this beer in a tasting and I always think to myself that this is a great beer but nothing more. Maybe Im missing something !

Bottle shared with Tweety...  Poured near black with amber highlights and a light brown head.  Aroma of dark brown sugars, oak, and grains.  Pretty hot, little bit of herbal-like hop notes, some malts, oak, sweet tones, and even earthy, vegetable-like qualities hinting towards bitter cabbage leaves.  Finished dry and malty.
Pours darkbrown with a beige head. Aroma is roasted malt, smoke and hop. Flavour is roasted malt, malt acidic, smoke and heavy alcohol.
Pours dark with a light foamy head.  The smell is of roasted malts, liquor and wood.  The taste is similar, but with a nice bitter bite to add to it.  It is very thick and delicious.

Bottle.

Dark brown, almost opaque with a small residing head.

Aroma is of smooth bourbon, almonds, toffee, chocolate and roasted malts.

The flavor is medium sweet and mildly bitter with smooth but prominent bourbon notes. Notes of chocolate, roasted malts, toffee and nuts. Ends somewhat dry and warming with hints of licorice and bourbon.

Medium to full body, could actually be somewhat more smooth.

A good beer, but Id take Older Viscosity before this one any day.

pours black as the devils soul with a dense tan head.  nose is raisen and toast and dark chocolate.  mouthfeel is heavy and thick, like a good motor oil should be.  taste is a little hot, with iodine and burnt toast.  the dark chocolate roasts come through at the end, along with a little alcohol bit.  a very, very good stout.  i will have to get a couple more for the cellar the next time im in chicago.

Pours nearly black. Tan fluffy head slowly going to lace. Caramel floral aroma. Flavor of roast malt, coffee, caramel, burned toast, raisin. Low carbonation. Medium to full body. Creamy feel. Dry bitter rough finish. Not real well rounded.Above average brew, but nothing spectacular.

Bomber. Pours a deep, opaque black body with a large tan head. Nice lacing. Aroma is sort of hidden but had some pretty good coffee, cinnamon, roasted chocolate malts, dark fruits(cherry) and some booze. Flavor is semi-sweet fruits and some chocolate. Cloves, light yeast, roasted coffee, and nice spices. Full bodied, smooth mouthfeel. Sweet, slight alcohol, dry finish. Very tasty brew!

Bottle side-by-side with older.  Pour is almost black with a thin brown head.  Head is lighter than older.  Aroma is quite roasty and malty with hints of coffee and vanilla.  Also notes of chocolate.  Flavor is very true to nose with lots of roasted malt, coffee and vanilla. Also notes of peat and smokiness.  Maybe a touch of fruitiness in there.  Solid and hides ETOh quite well.

Port Brewing
Old Viscosity
Pours jet black with a thin tan head. There is a slight reddish tinge at the edge of the glass. Oily on the glass in a big way. Aroma of coffee, brown sugar, and oil cured olives (really). Lasting aroma of pleasant alcohol. Flavor is slightly smoky with sweet under tones of coffee and chocolate. Aftertaste is coffee and alcohol. Darn good brew. Seems like a stout.

pours deep black witha thin deep mocha head...not much retention...oily looking.  has a barleywine like aroma with some coffee and burnt toffee as well...milky.  flavor has coffee, dark fruit, and a hint of chocolate.  moutfeely is lively given the appearance...oily too...roasty fruit finish.

For some reason, this beer always knocks me for a loop. Even more so than most bombers of 10%. It pours brown with a brown head. Thick, but not as thick as you might think. The aroma is of oak wood, vanilla, chocolate, nuts and raisins. The flavor is full of wood, raisins, plums, molasses, vanilla, a touch nutty but very sweet. A nice subtle roasted quality in the finish with more oak. Very flavorful, but lacks the next step of depth the the flavor profile. I give it a higher score for value. $6 a bomber aint bad for such a good beer.

A: The pour into a snifter is black. Pitch black with a small layer of mocha colored foam.

S: Interesting if not subtle aromas on this. Vanilla, roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, and some dark fruits.

T: Such a smooth flavor. Roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, vanilla, dark stone fruits, and a hint of alcohol round this one out. They might call it a strong ale, but its very reminiscent of an RIS.

M: The carbonation is low, but appropriate. The body is very full.

D: It packs a punch at 10%, but the booze does not really come through on the flavor. I had forgotten how much I enjoy this beer. A great offering from the folks at Port.

Appearance: 4/5
Pitch black liquid with a small light brown foam that left a curtain of lacing on the side of the glass.

Smell: 7/10
Chocolate, sweet, nuts.

Taste: 8/10
Chocolate, coffee, nuts, roasted and dark bread.

Mouthfeel: 4/5
Smooth, thick body, dry and mouth coating.

Comment:
It wasnt very complex, however felt well balanced, the flavours all complement each other in a good way. There also werent any off-flavours. The alcohol was well hidden, it only revealed itself in the alcoholic warmth that followed after taking a sip.

I liked this beer but I would have preferred it with a bit more flavour and complexity. The chocolate is definitely there but I would have liked some more coffee and dark malty flavours.

Sampled from a 22 oz brown bottle this beer poured thick, black and oily with a small dark brown head that lingered. The aroma was strong chocolate syrup, anise, rum and floral hops. The flavor was a delightful mix of cocoa, coffee, anise, rum, raisin, wood, port wine and floral hops. The finish was very long with cocoa and port wine lingering and turning a touch dry at the end. Full and smooth body. Excellent.

"Not your dads 30 weight"

-from the bottle

Poured from a bomber into my Duvel tulip glass.

Pours a pitch black color with no highlights what so ever. This is the darkest strong ale ive ever seen. I would call it an RIS or Double stout even. Initially there was a huge three and a half finger head that gave way to about a one finger head in 30 seconds or so. The head is a dark tan. Almost brownish color that actually showed some reddish highlights during the pour.

This one smells delicious. If i close my eyes i would swear there was a slice of double chocolate cake in front of me. And next to the cake is a mug full of fresh brewed sumatra coffee. Smells great. Lets get on to the tasting.

According to what ive read on this beer its blended with 20% that was aged in oak barrels. The oak is there if you look for it. I might not have noticed it had it not stated it on the bottle. The dominate flavors are chocolate and coffee. A touch of vanilla bean and oak. The booze is pretty much hidden other then a slight warmth in the gut after a few sips.

With the description on the label and the comparisons to used motor oil one would think this would have a super thick and heavy mouthfeel. Thats not the case. There is a creaminess and smoothness that i like. The beer is sweet throughout until the aftertaste where a tiny amount of bitterness comes through.
